div.p: EVERY ONE HAS HIS FAULT: A COMEDY, IN FIVE ACTS, AS IT IS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL, COVENT-GARDEN.
LONDON: PRINTED FOR G. G. J. AND J. ROBINSON, PATERNOSTER-ROW. 1793.

div.head: PROLOGUE.

lg.l: OUR Author, who accuſes great and ſmall,
And ſays ſo boldly, there are faults in all;
Sends me with diſmal voice, and lengthen'd phiz,
Humbly to own one dreadful fault of his:
A fault, in modern Authors not uncommon,
It is,—now don't be angry—He's—a woman.
Can you forgive it? Nay, I'll tell you more,
One who has dar'd to venture here before;
Has ſeen your ſmiles, your frowns,—tremendous ſight!
O, be not in a frowning mood to-night!
The Play, perhaps, has many things amiſs:
Well, let us then reduce the point to this,
Let only thoſe that have no failings, hiſs.
The Rights of Women, ſays a female pen,
Are, to do every thing as well as Men.
To think, to argue, to decide, to write,
To talk, undoubtedly—perhaps, to fight.
[For Females march to war, like brave Commanders,
Not in old Authors only—but in Flanders.]
I grant this matter may be ſtrain'd too far,
And Maid 'gainſt Man is moſt uncivil war:
I Grant, as all my City friends will ſay,
That Men ſhould rule, and Women ſhould obey:
That nothing binds the marriage contract faſter,
Than our—a "Zounds, Madam, I'm your Lord and Maſter."
I grant their nature, and their frailty ſuch,
Women may make too free—and know too much.
But ſince the Sex at length has been inclin'd
To cultivate that uſeful part—the mind;—
Since they have learnt to read, to write, to ſpell;—
Since ſome of them have wit,—and uſe it well;—
Let us not force them back with brow ſevere,
Within the pale of ignorance and fear,
Confin'd entirely to domeſtic arts,
Producing only children, pies, and tarts.
The fav'rite fable of the tuneful Nine,
Implies that female genius is divine.
Then, drive not, Critics, with tyrannic rage,
A ſupplicating Fair-one from the Stage;
The Comic Muſe perhaps is growing old,
Her lovers, you well know, are few and cold.
'Tis time then freely to enlarge the plan,
And let all thoſe write Comedies—that can.

div.head: DRAMATIS PERSONAE.
EVERY ONE HAS HIS FAULT: A COMEDY.
ACT I.
SCENE I. An Apartment at Mr. PLACID's.
div.stage: Enter Mr. PLACID and Mr. SOLUS.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: YOU are to blame.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: I ſay the ſame by you.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: And yet your ſingularity pleaſes me; for you are the firſt elderly bachelor I ever knew, who did not hug himſelf in the reflection, that he was not in the trammels of wedlock.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: No; I am only the firſt elderly bachelor who has truth and courage enough to confeſs his diſſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: And you really wiſh you were married?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: I do. I wiſh ſtill more, that I had been married thirty years ago. Oh! I wiſh a wife and half-a-ſcore children would now ſtart up around me, and bring along with them all that affection, which we ſhould have had for each other by being earlier acquainted. But as it is, in my preſent ſtate, there is not a perſon in the world I care a ſtraw for; and the world is pretty even with me, for I don't believe there is a creature in it who cares a ſtraw for me.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Pſhaw! You have in your time been a man of gallantry; and, conſequently, muſt have made many attachments.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Yes, ſuch as men of gallantry uſually make. I have been attached to women who have purloined my fortune, and to men who have partaken of the theft: I have been in as much fear of my miſtreſs as you are of your wife.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Is that poſſible?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Yes; and without having one of thoſe tender, delicate ties of a huſband, an excuſe for my apprehenſion.—I have maintained children—

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Then why do you complain for the want of a family?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p:
I did not ſay I ever had any children; I ſaid I had maintained them; but I never believed they were mine; for I could have no dependence upon the principles of their mother—and never did I
take one of thoſe tender infants in my arms, that the forehead of my Valet, the ſquint-eye of my Apothecary, or the double-chin of my Chaplain, did not ſtare me in the face, and damp all the fine feelings of the parent, which I had juſt called up.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: But thoſe are accidents which may occur in the marriage ſtate.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: In that caſe, a man is pitied—in mine, he is only laughed at.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: I wiſh to heaven I could exchange the pity which my friends beſtow on me, for the merriment which your ill fate excites.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: You want but courage to be envied.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Does any one doubt my courage?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: No. If a Prince were to offend you, you would challenge him, I have no doubt.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: But if my wife offend me, I am obliged to make an apology.—Was not that her voice? I hope ſhe has not overheard our converſation.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: If ſhe have, ſhe'll be in an ill humour.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: That ſhe will be, whether ſhe have heard it or not.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Well, good-day. I don't like to be driven from my fixed plan of wedlock; and, therefore, I won't be a ſpectator of your mutual diſcontent.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: But before you go, Mr. Solus, permit me to remind you of a certain concern, that, I think, would afford you much more delight, than all you can, at this time of life, propoſe to yourſelf in marriage. Make happy by your beneficence, a near relation whom the trueſt affection has drawn into that ſtate, but who is denied the bleſſing of competency to make the ſtate ſupportable.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: You mean my nephew, Irwin? But do not you acknowledge he has a wife and children? Did not he marry the woman he loved, and has he not, at this moment, a large family, by whom he is beloved? And is he not, therefore, with all his poverty, much happier than I? He has often told me, when I have reproached him with his indiſcreet marriage, "that in his wife he poſſeſſed kingdoms!" Do you ſuppoſe I will give any part of my fortune to a man who enjoys ſuch extenſive domains? No:—let him preſerve his territories, and I will keep my little eſtate for my own uſe. Exit.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: John! John!— Enter Servant Has your miſtreſs been enquiring for me?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Yes, Sir:—My Lady aſked juſt now, if I knew who was with you?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Did ſhe ſeem angry?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: No, Sir;—pretty well.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: You ſcoundrel, what do you mean by "pretty well?"In anger.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Much as uſual, Sir.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: And do you call that "pretty well?" You ſcoundrel, I have a great mind—

div.stage: Enter Mrs. PLACID, ſpeaking very loud.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: What is the matter, Mr. Placid? What is all this noiſe about? You know I hate a noiſe. What is the matter?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: My dear, I was only finding fault with that blockhead.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Placid, do not find fault with any body in this houſe. But I have ſomething which I muſt take you very ſeverely to talk about, Sir.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: No, my dear, not juſt now, pray.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Why not now?

sp.speaker: PLACID,
sp.p:
Becauſe dinner will be ready in a few minutes. I am very hungry, and it will be cruel of you
to ſpoil my appetite. John, is the dinner on table?

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: No, John, don't let it be ſerved yet—Mr. Placid, you ſhall firſt hear what I have to ſay.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: But then I know I ſha'n't be able to eat a morſel.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Sit down. He ſits—I believe, Mr. Placid, you are going to do a very ſilly thing. I am afraid you are going to lend ſome money?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Well, my dear, and ſuppoſe I am?

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Then, I don't approve of people lending their money.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: But, my dear, I have known you approve of borrowing money: And, once in our lives, what ſhould we have done, if every body had refuſed to lend?

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: That is nothing to the purpoſe.—And now I deſire you will hear what I ſay, without ſpeaking a word yourſelf.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Well, my dear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p:
Now mind you don't ſpeak, till I have done. —Our old acquaintance, Captain Irwin, and Lady
Eleanor, his wife (with whom we lived upon very intimate terms, to be ſure, while we were in America), are returned to London; and I find you have viſited them very frequently.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Not above two or three times, upon my word; for it hurts me to ſee them in diſtreſs, and I forbear to go.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: There! You own they are in diſtreſs; I expected as much. Now, own to me that they have aſked you to lend them money.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: I do own it—I do own it. Now, are you ſatisfied?

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: No: for I have no doubt but you have promiſed they ſhall have it.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: No, upon my word, I have not promiſed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Then promiſe me they ſhall not.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Nay, my dear, you have no idea of their diſtreſs!

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Yes, I have; and 'tis that which makes me ſuſpicious.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p:
His regiment is now broken; all her jewels and little bawbles are diſpoſed of; he is in ſuch dread of his old creditors, that, in the lodging they have taken, he paſſes by the name of Middleton—They have three more children, my dear, than when
we left them in New England; and they have in vain ſent repeated ſupplications, both to his uncle, and her father, for the ſmalleſt bounty.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: And is not Lord Norland, her father, a remarkably wiſe man? and a good man? And ought you to do for them, what he has refuſed?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: They have offended him, but they have never offended me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: I think 'tis an offence to aſk a friend for money, when there is no certainty of returning it.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: By no means: for, if there were a certainty, even an enemy might lend.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: But I inſiſt, Mr. Placid, that they ſhall not find a friend in you upon this occaſion.—What do you ſay, Sir?

sp.speaker: PLACID,
sp.p: No, my dear, they ſhall not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Poſitively ſhall not?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Poſitively ſhall not—ſince they have found an enemy in you.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Dinner is on table.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Ah! I am not hungry now.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: What do you mean by that, Mr. Placid? I inſiſt on your being hungry.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Oh yes! I have a very excellent appetite. I ſhall eat prodigiouſly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: You had beſt. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II. An Apartment at Mr. HARMONY's.
div.stage: Enter Mr. HARMONY followed by Miſs SPINSTER.

sp.speaker: Miſs SPINSTER.
sp.p: Couſin, couſin Harmony, I will not forgive you for thus continually ſpeaking in the behalf of every ſervant whom you find me offended with. Your philanthropy becomes inſupportable; and, inſtead of being a virtue, degenerates into a vice.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Dear Madam, do not upbraid me for a conſtitutional fault.

sp.speaker: Miſs SPINSTER.
sp.p: Very true; you had it from your infancy. I have heard your mother ſay you were always fooliſhly tender-hearted, and never ſhewed one of thoſe diſcriminating paſſions of envy, hatred, or revenge, to which all her other children were liable.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p:
No: ſince I can remember, I have felt the moſt unbounded affection for all my fellow creatures. I even proteſt to you, dear Madam, that, as I walk along the ſtreets of this large metropolis, ſo warm is my heart towards every perſon who paſſes me, that I long to ſay, "How do you do?" and
"I am glad to ſee you," to them all. Some men, I ſhould like even to ſtop and ſhake hands with;— and ſome women, I ſhould like even to ſtop and kiſs.

sp.speaker: Miſs SPINSTER.
sp.p: How can you be ſo ridiculous!

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis truth: and I ſincerely lament that human beings ſhould be ſuch ſtrangers to one another as we are. We live in the ſame ſtreet, without knowing one another's neceſſities; and oftentimes meet and part from each other at church, at coffee-houſes, play-houſes, and all public places, without ever ſpeaking a ſingle word, or nodding "Good bye!" though 'tis a hundred chances to ten we never ſee one another again.

sp.speaker: Miſs SPINSTER.
sp.p: Let me tell you, kinſman, all this pretended philanthropy renders you ridiculous. There is not a fraud, a theft, or hardly any vice committed, that you do not take the criminal's part, ſhake your head, and cry, "Proviſions are ſo ſcarce!" And no longer ago than laſt Lord-mayor's-day, when you were told that Mr. Alderman Ravenous was ill with an indigeſtion, you endeavoured to ſoften the matter, by exclaiming, "Proviſions are ſo ſcarce!"—But, above all, I condemn that falſe humanity, which induces you to ſay many things in converſation which deſerve to ſtigmatize you with the character of deceit.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p:
This is a weakneſs I confeſs. But though my honour ſometimes reproaches me with it as a fault, my conſcience never does: for it is by this very failing that I have frequently made the bittereſt
enemies friends—Juſt by ſaying a few harmleſs ſentences, which, though a ſpecies of falſehood and deceit, yet, being ſoothing and acceptable to the perſon offended, I have immediately inſpired him with lenity and forgiveneſs; and then, by only repeating the ſelf-ſame ſentences to his opponent, I have known hearts cold and cloſed to each other, warmed and expanded, as every human creature's ought to be.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Mr. Solus. Exit Servant.

sp.speaker: Miſs SPINSTER.
sp.p: I cannot think, Mr. Harmony, why you keep company with that old bachelor; he is a man, of all others on earth, I diſlike; and ſo I am obliged to quit the room, though I have a thouſand things to ſay. Exit angrily.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Mr. Solus, how do you do?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: I am very lonely at home; will you come and dine with me?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Now you are here, you had better ſtay with me: we have no company; only my couſin Miſs Spinſter and myſelf.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: No, I muſt go home: do come to my houſe.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Nay, pray ſtay: what objection can you have?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Why, to tell you the truth, your relation, Miſs Spinſter, is no great favourite of mine; and I don't like to dine with you, becauſe I don't like her company.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: That is, to me, ſurpriſing!

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Why, old bachelors and old maids never agree: we are too much alike in our habits: we know our own hearts ſo well, we are apt to diſcover every foible we would wiſh to forget, in the ſymptoms diſplayed by the other. Miſs Spinſter is peeviſh, fretful and tireſome, and I am always in a fidget when I am in her company.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: How different are her ſentiments of you! for one of her greateſt joys is to be in your company. Solus ſtarts and ſmiles Poor woman! ſhe has, to be ſure, an uneven temper—

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: No, perhaps I am miſtaken.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: —But I will aſſure you, I never ſee her in half ſuch good humour as when you are here: for I believe you are the greateſt favourite ſhe has.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: I am very much obliged to her, and I certainly am miſtaken about her temper—Some people, if they look ever ſo croſs, are good-natured in the main; and I dare ſay ſhe is ſo. Beſides, ſhe never has had a huſband to ſooth and ſoften her diſpoſition; and there ſhould be ſome allowance made for that.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Will you dine with us?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: I don't care if I do. Yes, I think I will. I muſt however ſtep home firſt:—but I'll be back in a quarter of an hour.—My compliments to Miſs Spinſter, if you ſhould ſee her before I return.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: My lady begs to know, Sir, if you have invited Mr. Solus to dine? becauſe if you have, ſhe ſhall go out. Exit Servant.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, I could not help inviting him; for, poor man, his own houſe is in ſuch a ſtate for want of proper management, he cannot give a comfortable dinner himſelf.

sp.speaker: Miſs SPINSTER.
sp.p: And ſo he muſt ſpoil the comfort of mine.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Poor man! poor man! after all the praiſes he has been laviſhing upon you.

sp.speaker: Miſs SPINSTER.
sp.p: What praiſes?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I won't tell you; for you won't believe them.

sp.speaker: Miſs SPINSTER.
sp.p: Yes, I ſhall.—Oh no—now I recollect, this is ſome of your invention.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Nay, I told him it was his invention: for he declared you looked better laſt night, than any other lady at the Opera.

sp.speaker: Miſs SPINSTER.
sp.p: No, this ſounds like truth: —and, depend upon it, though I never liked the manners of Mr. Solus much, yet—

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Nay, Solus has his faults.

sp.speaker: Miſs SPINSTER.
sp.p: So we have all.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: And will you leave him and me to dine by ourſelves?

sp.speaker: Miſs SPINSTER.
sp.p: Oh no, I cannot be guilty of ſuch ill manners, though I talked of it. Beſides, poor Mr. Solus does not come ſo often, and it would be wrong not to ſhew him all the civility we can. For my part, I have no diſlike to the man; and, if taking a bit of dinner with us now and then can oblige either you or him, I ſhould be to blame to make any objection. Come, let us go into the drawing-room to receive him.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Ay! this is right: this is as it ſhould be.

div.head: SCENE III. A Room at the Lodgings of Mr. IRWIN.
div.stage: Mr. IRWIN and Lady ELEANOR IRWIN diſcovered.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: My dear huſband, my dear Irwin, I cannot bear to ſee you thus melancholy. Is this the joy of returning to our native country after a nine years baniſhment?

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p:
Yes. For I could bear my misfortunes, my
wretched poverty with patience, in a land where our ſorrows were ſhared by thoſe about us; but here, in London, where plenty and eaſe ſmile upon every face; where, by birth you claim diſtinction, and I by ſervices:—here to be in want,—to be obliged to take another name in ſhame of our own,—to tremble at the voice of every ſtranger, for fear he ſhould be a creditor,—to meet each old acquaintance with an averted eye, becauſe we would not feel the pang of being ſhunned.—To have no reward for all this, even in a comfortable home; but there, to ſee our children looking up to me for that ſupport I have not in my power to give—Can I,—can I love them and you, and not be miſerable?

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: And yet I am not ſo. And I am ſure you will not doubt my love to you or them.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: I met my uncle this morning, and was mean enough to repeat my requeſt to him;—he burſt into a fit of laughter, and told me my diſtreſſes were the reſult of my ambition, in marrying the daughter of a nobleman, who himſelf was too ambitious ever to pardon us.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Tell me no more of what he ſaid.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: This was a day of trials:—I ſaw your father too.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: My father! Lord Norland! Oh Heavens!

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: He paſſed me in his carriage.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: I envy you the bleſſing of ſeeing him! For, Oh!—Excuſe my tears —he is my father ſtill.— How did he look?

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: As well as he did at the time I uſed to watch him from his houſe, to ſteal to you.—But I am ſorry to acquaint you, that, to guard himſelf againſt all returning love for you, he has, I am informed, adopted a young lad, on whom he beſtows every mark of that paternal affection, of which you lament the loſs.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: May the young man deſerve his tenderneſs better than I have done—May he never diſobey him —May he be a comfort, and cheriſh his benefactor's declining years—And when his youthful paſſions teach him to love, may they not, like mine, teach him diſobedience!

div.stage: Enter a SERVANT with a letter.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: What is that letter?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: It comes from Mr. Placid, the ſervant who brought it, ſaid, and requires no anſwer. Exit.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p:
It's ſtrange how I tremble at every letter I ſee, as if I dreaded the contents. How poverty has unmann'd me! aſide—I muſt tell you, my dear, that finding myſelf left this morning without a guinea, I wrote to Mr. Placid to borrow a ſmall ſum. This is his anſwer: reading the ſuperſcription "To Mr. Middleton"—That's right;—he remembers the caution I gave him. I had forgot whether
I had, for my memory is not ſo good as it was. I did not even recollect this hand, though it is one I am ſo well acquainted with, and ought to give me joy rather than ſorrow Opens the letter haſtily, reads, and lets it drop. Now I have not a friend on earth.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Yes, you have me. You forget me.

sp.speaker: IRWIN,
sp.p: I would forget you—you—and all your children.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: I would not loſe the remembrance of you, or of them, for all my father's fortune.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: What am I to do? I muſt leave you! I muſt go, I know not where! I cannot ſtay to ſee you periſh. Takes his hat, and is going.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR,
sp.p: Where would you go? 'Tis evening—'tis dark —Whither would you go at this time?

sp.speaker: IRWIN,
sp.p: I muſt conſider what's to be done—and in this room my thoughts are too confined to reflect.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: And are London ſtreets calculated for reflection?

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: No;—for action. To hurry the faint thought to reſolution.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: You are not well—Your health has been lately impaired.—Your temper has undergone a change too:—I tremble leſt any accident—

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: What accident?Wildly

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: I know your provocations from an ungrateful world: But deſpiſe it, as that deſpiſes you.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: But for your ſake, I could.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Then witneſs, Heaven! I am happy.—Though bred in all the delicacy, the luxury of wealth and ſplendour; yet I have never murmured at the change of fortune, while that change has made me wife to you, and mother of your children.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: We will be happy—if poſſible. But give me this evening to conſider what plan to fix upon.— There is no time to loſe; we are without friends —without money—without credit.—Farewell for an hour.—I will ſee Mr. Placid, if I can; and though he have not the money to lend, he may, perhaps, give me ſome advice.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Suppoſe I call on her? Women are ſometimes more conſiderate than men, and—

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Do you for the beſt, and ſo will I.—Heavens bleſs you!Exeunt ſeparately.

div.head: ACT II.
SCENE I. A Coffee or Club-room at a Tavern.
div.stage: Enter Sir ROBERT RAMBLE—and Mr. SOLUS and Mr. PLACID at the oppoſite Side.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: SIR Robert Ramble, how do you do?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: My dear Mr. Solus, I am glad to ſee you. I have been dining by myſelf, and now come into this public room to meet with ſome good company.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Ay, Sir Robert, you are now reduced to the ſame neceſſity which I frequently am—I frequently am obliged to dine at taverns and coffee-houſes, for want of company at home.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Nay, I proteſt I am never happier than in a houſe like this, where a man may meet his friend without the inconvenience of form, either as a hoſt or a viſitor.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Sir Robert, give me leave to introduce to you Mr. Placid: he has been many years abroad; but I believe he now means to remain in his own country for the reſt of his life. This, Mr. Placid, is Sir Robert Ramble.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT,
sp.p: Sir, I ſhall be happy in your acquaintance; and I aſſure you, if you will do me the honour to meet me now and then at this houſe, you will find every thing very pleaſant. I verily believe, that ſince I loſt my wife, which is now about five months ago, I verily believe I have dined here three days out of the ſeven.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Have you loſt your wife, Sir? And ſo lately?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT,
sp.p: Yes, Sir; about five months ago—Is it not, Mr. Solus? You keep account of ſuch things better than I do.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Oh! aſk me no queſtions about your wife, Sir Robert; if ſhe had been mine, I would have had her to this moment.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: What, wreſted her from the gripe of death?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: No, Sir; only from the gripe of the Scotch lawyers.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: More ſhame for you. Shame! to wiſh to be divorced from a virtuous wife.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Was that the caſe? Divorced from a virtuous wife! I never heard of ſuch a circumſtance before. Pray, Sir Robert very anxiouſly, will you indulge me, by letting me know in what manner you were able to bring about ſo great an event?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: It may appear ſtrange to you, Sir; but my wife and I did not live happy together.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Not at all ſtrange, Sir; I can conceive—I can conceive very well.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Yes; he can conceive that part to a nicety.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: And ſo, I was determined on a divorce.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: But then her character could not be unimpeached.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Yes, it was, Sir. You muſt know, we were married in Scotland, and by the laws there, a wife can divorce her huſband for breach of fidelity; and ſo, though my wife's character was unimpeached, mine was not, and ſhe divorced me.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: And is this the law in Scotland?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: It is. Bleſſed, bleſſed country! that will bind young people together before the years of diſcretion—and, as ſoon as they have diſcretion to repent, will unbind them again!

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: I wiſh I had been married in Scotland.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: But, Sir Robert, with all this boaſting, you muſt own that your divorce has greatly diminiſhed your fortune.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT,
sp.p: Mr. Solus, you have frequently hinted at my fortune being impaired; but I do not approve of ſuch notions being received abroad.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: I beg your pardon; but every body knows that you have played very deep lately, and have been a great loſer, and every body knows—

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: No, Sir, every body does not know it, for I contradict the report wherever I go. A man of faſhion does not like to be reckoned poor, no more than he likes to be reckoned unhappy. We none of us endeavour to be happy, Sir, but merely to be thought ſo; and for my part, I had rather be in a ſtate of miſery, and envied for my ſuppoſed happineſs, than in a ſtate of happineſs, and pitied for my ſuppoſed miſery.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: But conſider, theſe misfortunes which I have juſt hinted at, are not of any ſerious nature, only ſuch as a few years oeconomy—

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: But were my wife and her guardian to become acquainted with theſe little misfortunes, they would triumph in my embarraſſments.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Lady Ramble triumph! They join Mr. Placid She who was ſo firmly attached to you, that I believe nothing but a compliance with your repeated requeſt to be ſeparated, cauſed her to take the ſtep ſhe did.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Yes, I believe ſhe did it to oblige me, and I am very much obliged to her.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: As good a woman, Mr. Placid—

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Very good—but very ugly.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: She is beautiful.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT,
sp.p: I tell you, Sir, ſhe is hideous. And then ſhe was grown ſo inſufferably peeviſh.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: I never ſaw her out of temper.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Mr. Solus, it is very uncivil of you to praiſe her before my face. Lady Ramble, at the time I parted with her, had every poſſible fault both of mind and perſon, and ſo I made love to other women in her preſence; told her bluntly that I was tired of her; that I was very ſorry to make her uneaſy, but that I could not love her any longer.—And was not that frank and open?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Oh! that I had but ſuch a wife as ſhe was!

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: I muſt own I loved her myſelf when ſhe was young.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Do you call her old?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: In years I am certainly older than ſhe; but the difference of ſex makes her a great deal older than I am. For inſtance, Mr. Solus, you have often lamented not being married in your youth; but if you had, what would you have now done with an old wife, a woman of your own age?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Loved and cheriſhed her.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: What, in ſpite of her loſs of beauty?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: When ſhe had loſt her beauty; moſt likely I ſhould have loſt my eye-ſight, and have been blind to the wane of her charms.

sp.speaker: PLACID,
sp.p: But, Sir Robert, you were explaining to me— Mr. Solus, give me leave to ſpeak to Sir Robert —I feel myſelf particularly intereſted on this ſubject.—And, Sir, you were explaining to me—

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Very true: Where did I leave off? Oh! at my ill uſage of my Lady Ramble. Yes, I did uſe her very ill, and yet ſhe loved me. Many a time, when ſhe has ſaid to me, "Sir Robert, I deteſt your principles, your manners, and even your perſon," often, at that very inſtant, I have ſeen a little ſparkle of a wiſh peep out of the corner of one eye, that has called to me, "Oh! Sir Robert, how I long to make it up with you!"

sp.speaker: SOLUS,
sp.p: Do not you wiſh that your wife had ſuch a little ſparkle at the corner of one of her eyes?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert,
sp.p: Sir, do you wiſh to be divorced?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: I have no ſuch proſpect. Mrs. Placid is faithful, and I was married in England.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: But if you have an unconquerable deſire to part, a ſeparate maintenance will anſwer nearly the ſame end—for if your Lady and you will only lay down the plan of ſeparation, and agree—

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: But, unfortunately, we never do agree!

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Then ſpeak of parting as a thing you dread worſe than death; and make it your daily prayer to her, that ſhe will never think of going from you—She will determine upon it directly.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: I thank you; I'm very much obliged to you: I thank you a thouſand times.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Yes, I have ſtudied the art of teaſing a wife; and there is nothing vexes her ſo much as laughing at her. Can you laugh, Mr. Placid?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: I don't know whether I can; I have not laughed ſince I married.—But I thank you, Sir, for your inſtructions—I ſincerely thank you.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: And now, Sir Robert, you have had the good nature to teach this Gentleman how to get rid of his wife, will you have the kindneſs to teach me how to procure one?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Hah! Sure I know that Gentleman's face?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: My Nephew! Let me eſcape his ſolicitations Aſide—Here, waiter!Exit.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Irwin! Starting Having ſent him a denial, I am aſhamed to ſee him. Aſide Here, Mr. Solus!— Exit, following Mr. SOLUS.

sp.speaker: IRWIN,
sp.p: More cool faces! My neceſſitous countenance clears even a club-room.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: My dear Captain Irwin, is it you? Yes, 'faith it is—After a nine years' abſence I moſt ſincerely rejoice to ſee you.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Sir Robert, you ſhake hands with a cordiality I have not experienced theſe many days, and I thank you.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: But what's the matter? You ſeem to droop— Where have you left your uſual ſpirits? Has abſence from your country changed your manners?

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: No, Sir; but I find ſome of my countrymen changed. I fancy them leſs warm, leſs friendly than they were; and it is that which, perhaps, has this effect upon me.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Am I changed?

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: You appear an exception.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: And I aſſure you, that inſtead of being grown more gloomy, I am even more gay than I was ſeven years ago; for then, I was upon the point of matrimony—but now, I am juſt relieved from its cares.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: I have heard as much. But I hope you have not taken ſo great an averſion to the marriage-ſtate, as never to marry again.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Perhaps not: But then it muſt be to ſome rich heireſs.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: You are right to pay reſpect to fortune. Money is a neceſſary article in the marriage contract.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: As to that—that would be no great object at preſent. No, thank Heaven, my eſtates are pretty large; I have no children; I have a rich Uncle, excellent health, admirable ſpirits; — and thus happy, it would be very ſtrange if I did not meet my old friends with thoſe ſmiles, which never for a moment quit my countenance.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: In the diſpenſation of the gifts of Providence, how few are found bleſt like you!Sighing.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: And I allure you, my dear Mr. Irwin, it gives me the moſt ſerious reflections, and the moſt ſincere concern, that they are not.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir, moſt heartily: I thank you for mankind in general, and for myſelf in particular. For after this generous, unaffected declaration (with leſs ſcruple than I ſhould to any man in the world) I will own to you, that I am at this very time in the utmoſt want of an act of friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT,
sp.p: And ſo am I—Now muſt I confeſs myſelf a poor man; or paſs for an unfeeling one; and I will chooſe the latter. Bowing with great ceremony and coldneſs, Any thing that I can command, is at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Why then, Sir Robert—I am almoſt aſhamed to ſay it—but circumſtances have been rather unfavourable.—My wife's father affecting to ſmile is not reconciled to us yet—My regiment is broke —My Uncle will not part with a farthing.—Lady Eleanor, my wife, wipes his eyes has been ſupported as yet, with ſome little degree of tenderneſs, elegance; and—in ſhort, I owe a ſmall ſum which I am afraid of being troubled for; I want a trifle alſo for our immediate uſe, and if you would lend me a hundred pounds—though, upon my honour, I am not in a ſituation to fix the exact time when I can pay it.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: My dear Sir, never trouble yourſelf about the time of paying it, becauſe it happens not to be in my power to lend it you.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Not in your power? I beg your pardon; but have not you this moment been ſaying you are rich?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: And is it not very common to be rich without money? Are not half the town rich? And yet half the town has no money. I ſpeak for this end of the town, the Weſt end. The Squares, for inſtance, part of Piccadilly, down St. James's-ſtreet, and ſo home by Pall Mall. We have all, eſtates, bonds, drafts, and notes of hand without number; but as for money, we have no ſuch thing belonging to us.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p:
I ſincerely beg your pardon. And be aſſured, Sir, nothing ſhould have induced me to have taken
the liberty I have done, but the neceſſities of my unhappy family, and having underſtood by your own words, that you were in affluence.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: I am in affluence, I am, I am; but not in ſo much, perhaps, as my haſty, inconſiderate account may have given you reaſon to believe. I forgot to mention ſeveral heavy incumbrances, which you will perceive are great drawbacks on my fortune.—As my wife ſued for the divorce, I have her fortune to return; I have alſo two ſiſters to portion off—a circumſtance I totally forgot. But, my good friend, though I am not in circumſtances to do what you require, I will do ſomething that ſhall be better. I'll wait upon your father-in-law, (Lord Norland) and entreat him to forgive his daughter: and I am ſure he will if I aſk him.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: And ſo it is, now I recollect: for he is no other than the guardian of my late wife, and a requeſt from me, will be received worſe than from any other perſon. — However, Mr. Irwin, depend upon it, that whenever I have an opportunity of ſerving you, I will. And whenever you ſhall do me the favour to call upon me, I ſhall be heartily glad to ſee you. If I am not at home, you can leave your card, which, you know, is all the ſame, and depend upon it, I ſhall be extremely glad to ſee you or that, at any time. Exit.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p:
Is this my native country? Is this the hoſpitable land which we deſcribe to ſtrangers? No—We are ſavages to each other; nay worſe—The ſavage
makes his fellow-ſavage welcome; divides with him his homely fare; gives him the beſt apartment his hut affords, and tries to huſh thoſe griefs that are confided in his boſom—While in this civilized city, among my own countrymen, even among my brother officers in the army, and many of my neareſt relations, ſo very civilized they are, I could not take the liberty to enter under one roof, without a ceremonious invitation, and that they will not give me. I may leave my card at their door, but as for me, or any one of mine, they would not give us a dinner; unleſs, indeed, it was in ſuch a ſtyle, that we might behold with admiration their grandeur, and return ſtill more depreſſed, to our own poverty.—Can I bear this treatment longer? No, not even for you, my Eleanor. And this takes out a piſtol ſhall now be the only friend to whom I will apply—And yet I want the courage to be a villain.

div.stage: Enter Mr. HARMONY, ſpeaking as he enters.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Let me ſee half a dozen newſpapers—Every paper of the day.

sp.speaker: WAITER.
sp.p: That is about three dozen, Sir.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Get a couple of porters, and bring them all.

div.stage: He ſits down; they bring him papers, and he reads—Irwin ſtarts, ſits down, leans his head on one of the tables, and ſhews various ſigns of uneaſineſs; then comes forward.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p:
Am I a man, a ſoldier?—And a coward? Yes,
I run away, I turn my back on life—I forſake the poſt, which my commander, Providence, has allotted me, and fly before a banditti of rude miſfortunes. Rally me, love, connubial and parental love, rally me back to the charge! No, thoſe very affections ſound the retreat. Sits down with the ſame emotions of diſtraction as before.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: That gentleman does not ſeem happy. I wiſh I had an opportunity of ſpeaking to him. Aſide.

sp.speaker: IRWIN
sp.p: But Oh! my wife, what will be your ſufferings when I am brought home to your wretched habitation!—And by my own hand!

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I am afraid, Sir, I engroſs all the news here.

sp.speaker: IRWIN,
sp.p: Poor ſoul, how her heart will be torn!

sp.speaker: HARMONY,
sp.p: Captain Irwin, till this moment I had not the pleaſure of recollecting you! It is Mr. Irwin, is it not?

sp.speaker: IRWIN,
sp.stage: His mind deranged by his misfortunes.
sp.p: Yes, Sir: But what have you to ſay to him more than to a ſtranger?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p:
Nothing more, Sir, than to apologize to you, for having addreſſed you juſt now in ſo familiar a manner, before I knew who you were; and to aſſure you, that although I have no other knowledge of you, than from report, and having been once, I believe, in your company at this very
houſe before you left England; yet, any ſervices of mine, as far as my abilities can reach, you may freely command.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, do you live at the Weſt end of the town?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Then, Sir, your ſervices can be of no uſe to me.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Here is the place where I live, here is my card.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: And here is mine. And now I preſume we have exchanged every act of friendſhip, which the ſtrict forms of etiquette, in this town, will admit of.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: By no means, Sir. I aſſure you my profeſſions never go beyond my intentions; and if there is any thing that I can ſerve you in—

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Have you no ſiſters to portion off? no lady's fortune to return? Or, perhaps, you will ſpeak to my wife's father, and entreat him to forgive his child.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: On that ſubject you may command me; for I have the honour to be intimately acquainted with Lord Norland.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: But is there no reaſon you may recollect, "why you would be the moſt unfit perſon in the world to apply to him?"

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: None. I have been honoured with marks of his friendſhip for many years paſt; and I do not know any one who could, with leſs hazard of his reſentment, venture to name his daughter to him.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Well, Sir, if you ſhould ſee him two or three days hence, when I am ſet out on a journey I am going, if you will then ſay a kind word to him for my wife and children, I'll thank you.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I will go to him inſtantly. Going.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: No, do not ſee him yet; ſtay till I am gone. He will do nothing till I am gone.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: May I aſk where you are going?

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: No very tedious journey; but it is a country, to thoſe who go without a proper paſſport, always fatal.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I'll ſee Lord Norland to-night: perhaps I may perſuade him to prevent your journey. I'll ſee him to-night, or early in the morning, depend upon it.—I am a man of my word, Sir; though I muſt own I do live at the Weſt end of the town.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p:
'Sdeath, am I become the ridicule of my fellow-creatures? or am I not in my ſenſes?—I know this is London—this houſe a tavern—I know I have a wife. Oh! 'twere better to be mad than to remember her! She has a father—he is rich and proud—that I will not forget. But I will paſs his houſe, and ſend a malediction as I paſs it— furiouſly.
No; breathe out my laſt ſigh at his inhoſpitable door, and that ſigh ſhall breathe—forgiveneſs. Exit.

div.head: SCENE II. The Lodgings of Mr. IRWIN.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. PLACID, followed by Lady ELEANOR IRWIN.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: I am aſhamed of the trouble I have given you, Mrs. Placid. It had been ſufficient to have ſent me home in your carriage; to attend me yourſelf was ceremonious.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: My dear Lady Eleanor, I was reſolved to come home with you, as ſoon as Mr. Placid deſired I would not.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Was that the cauſe of your politeneſs? I am ſorry it ſhould.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Why ſorry? It is not proper he ſhould have his way in every thing.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: But I am afraid you ſeldom let him have it at all.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Yes, I do.—But where, my dear, is Mr. Irwin?

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR,
sp.p: I cannot hear the name of Mr. Irwin without ſhedding tears: his health has been ſo much impaired of late, and his ſpirits ſo bad—ſometimes I even fear for a failure in his mind. Weeps again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Is not he at home?

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: I hope he is Goes to the ſide of the ſcenes. Tell your maſter, Mrs. Placid is here.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: My maſter is not come in yet, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Not yet? I am very ſorry for it;—very ſorry indeed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Bleſs me, my dear, don't look thus pale. Come ſit down, and I'll ſtay with you till he returns.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: My dear, you forget that Mr. Placid is in the carriage at the door all this time.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: No, I don't. Come, let us ſit and have half an hour's converſation.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Nay, I inſiſt upon your going to him, or deſiring him to walk in.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p:
Now I think of it, they may as well drive him home, and come back for me.
Enter Mr. PLACID. Why ſurely, Mr. Placid, you were very impatient! I think you might have waited a few minutes longer.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: I would have waited, my dear, but the evening is ſo damp.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Ah! 'tis the evening, which makes me alarmed for Mr. Irwin.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Lady Eleanor, you are one of the moſt tender, anxious, and affectionate wives I ever knew.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: There! Now he wiſhes he was your huſband— He admires the conduct of every wife but his own, and envies every married man of his acquaintance. But it is very ungenerous of you.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: So it is, my dear; and not at all conſiſtent with the law of retaliation; for I am ſure there is not one of my acquaintance who envies me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Mr. Placid, your behaviour throughout this whole day has been ſo totally different to what it ever was before, that I am half reſolved to live no longer with you.

sp.speaker: PLACID,
sp.p: It will do—It will do.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Oh, my dear friends, do not talk of parting: how can you, while every bleſſing ſmiles on your union? Even I, who have reaſon to regret mine, yet, while that load of grief, a ſeparation from Mr. Irwin, is but averted, I will think every other affliction ſupportable. A loud rapping at the door. That is he.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Why, you ſeem in raptures at his return.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: I know no greater rapture.

div.stage: Enter IRWIN pale, trembling, and diſordered.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: My dear, you are not well, I ſee.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Yes.— Aſide to her in anger—Why do you ſpeak of it?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: How do you do, Irwin?

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: I am glad to ſee you. Bows.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: But I am ſorry to ſee you look ſo ill.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: I have only been taking a glaſs too much.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Pſhaw! Don't I know you never drink?

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: You are miſtaken: I do when my wife is not by. I am afraid of her.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Impoſſible.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: What! To be afraid of one's wife?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: No; I think that very poſſible.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
IRWIN.
sp.p:
I will, Madam, Shaking hands with Placid. And do you keep up your ſpirits.
Exeunt Mr. and Mrs. Placid. Irwin ſhuts the door with care after them, and looks round the room as if he feared to be ſeen or overheard.
I am glad they are gone. I ſpoke unkindly to you juſt now, did I not? My temper is altered lately; and yet I love you.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: I never doubted it, nor ever will.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: If you did, you would wrong me; for there is not a danger I would not riſk for your ſake; there is not an infamy I would not be branded with to make you happy, nor a puniſhment I would not undergo, with joy, for your welfare.—But there is a bar to this; we are unfortunately ſo entwined together, ſo linked, ſo rivetted, ſo cruelly, painfully fettered to each other, you could not be happy unleſs I ſhared the ſelf ſame happineſs with you. —But you will learn better—now you are in London, and amongſt faſhionable wives; you muſt learn better. Walks about and ſmiles, with a ghaſtly countenance.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Do not talk, do not look thus wildly—Indeed, indeed, you make me very uneaſy.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p:
What! uneaſy when I come to bring you comfort; and ſuch comfort as you have not experienced
for many a day? He pulls out a pocket-book. Here is a friend in our neceſſity,—a friend that brings a thouſand friends; plenty and—no, not always— peace. He takes ſeveral papers from the book, and puts them into her hands—She looks at them, then ſcreams.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Ah! 'Tis money. Trembling. Theſe are Bank notes.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Huſh! For heaven's ſake, huſh! We ſhall be diſcovered. Trembling and in great perturbation. What alarms you thus?

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: What alarms you?

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Do you ſay I am frightened?

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: A ſight ſo new has frightened me.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Nay, they are your own: by heaven, they are! No one on earth has a better, or a fairer right than you have. It was a laudable act by which I obtained them.—The parent-bird had forſook its young, and I but forced it back to perform the rites of nature.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: You are inſane, I fear. No, no, I do not fear— hope you are.

div.stage: A loud rapping at the ſtreet-door—He ſtarts, takes the notes from her, and puts them haſtily into his pocket.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Go to the door yourſelf; and if 'tis any one who aſks for me, ſay I am not come home yet.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: It is the perſon belonging to the houſe: no one to us.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: My dear Eleanor, are you willing to quit London with me in about two hours time?

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Inſtantly.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: Nay, not only London, but England.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: This world, if you deſire it. To go in company with you, will make the journey pleaſant; and all I loved on earth would ſtill be with me.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: You can, then, leave your father without regret, never, never to ſee him more?

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Why ſhould I think on him, who will not think of me?Weeps.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: But our children—

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: We are not to leave them behind?

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: One of them we muſt: but do not let that give you uneaſineſs. You know he has never lived with us ſince his infancy, and cannot pine for the loſs of parents whom he has never known.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p:
But I have known him. He was my firſt; and, ſometimes, I think more cloſely wound around my heart, than all the reſt. The grief I felt on being forced to leave him when we went
abroad, and the conſtant anxiety I have ſince experienced leſt he ſhould not be kindly treated, have augmented, I think, my tenderneſs.

sp.speaker: IRWIN.
sp.p: All my endeavours to-day, as well as every other day, have been in vain to find into what part of the country his nurſe has taken him.—Nay, be not thus overcome with tears; we will (in ſpite of all my haſte to be gone) ſtay one more miſerable day here, in hopes to procure intelligence, ſo as to take him with us; and then ſmile with contempt on all we leave behind. Exeunt.

div.head: ACT III.
SCENE I. A Library at Lord NORLAND's.
div.stage: Enter Lord NORLAND, followed by Mr. HARMONY.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND,
sp.p: I TELL you, Mr. Harmony, that if an indifferent perſon, one on whom I had never beſtowed a favour in my life, were to offend me, it is in my nature never to forgive. Can I then forgive my own daughter, my only child, on whom I heaped continually marks of the moſt affectionate fondneſs? Shall ſhe dare to offend me in the tendereſt point, and you dare to ſuppoſe I will pardon her?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Your child, conſider.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: The weakeſt argument you can uſe. As my child, was not ſhe moſt bound to obey me? As my child, ought ſhe not to have ſacrificed her own happineſs to mine? Inſtead of which, mine has been yielded up for a whim, a fancy, a fancy to marry a beggar; and as ſuch is her choice, let her beg with him.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: She does by me;—pleads hard for your forgiveneſs.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p:
If I thought ſhe dared to ſend a meſſage to me, though dictated on her knees, ſhe ſhould find
that ſhe had not yet felt the full force of my reſentment.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: What could you do more?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I have done nothing yet. At preſent, I have only abandoned her;—but I can perſecute.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I have no doubt of it: and, that I may not be the means of aggravating your diſpleaſure, I aſſure you, that what I have now ſaid has been entirely from myſelf, without any deſire of hers; and, at the ſame time, I give you my promiſe, I will never preſume to intrude the ſubject again.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: On this condition (but on no other) I forgive you now.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: And now then, my Lord, let us paſs from thoſe who have forfeited your love, to thoſe who poſſeſs it.—I heard ſome time ago, but I never preſumed to mention it to you, that you had adopted a young man as your ſon?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: "A young man!" Pſhaw!—No; a boy—a mere child, who fell in my way by accident.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: A chance child! Ho! ho!—I underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Do not jeſt with me, Sir. Do I look—

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Yes, you look as if you would be aſhamed to own it, if you had one.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: But this boy I am not aſhamed of:—he is a favourite—rather a favourite.—I did not like him ſo well at firſt;—but cuſtom,—and having a poor creature entirely at one's mercy, one begins to love it merely from the idea of—What would be its fate if one did not?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Is he an orphan then?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: You have a friendſhip for his parents?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I never ſaw the father: his mother I had a friendſhip for once. Sighing.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Ay, while the huſband was away?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I tell you, no. violently—But aſk no more queſtions. Who his parents are, is a ſecret, which neither he, nor any one (that is now living) knows, except myſelf; nor ever ſhall.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Well, my Lord, ſince 'tis your pleaſure to conſider him as your child, I ſincerely with you may experience more duty from him than you have done from your daughter.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Thank Heaven, his diſpoſition is not in the leaſt like her's.—No: very much impaſſioned I have the joy to ſay, that never child was ſo unlike its mother.

sp.speaker: HARMONY,
sp.p: How! His mother!

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Confuſion!—what have I ſaid?—I am aſhamed—

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: No,—be proud.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: That you have a lawful heir to all your riches; proud that you have a grandſon.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I would have concealed it from all the world; I wiſhed it even unknown to myſelf. And let me tell you, Sir, (as not by my deſign, but through my inadvertency, you are become acquainted with this ſecret) that, if ever you breathe it to a ſingle creature, the boy ſhall anſwer for it; for, were he known to be her's, though he were dearer to me than ever ſhe was, I would turn him from my houſe, and caſt him from my heart, as I have done her.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I believe you;—and in compaſſion to the child, give you my ſolemn promiſe never to reveal who he is. I have heard that thoſe unfortunate parents left an infant behind when they went abroad, and that they now lament him as loſt. Will you ſatiſfy my curioſity, in what manner you ſought and found him out?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p:
Do you ſuppoſe I ſearched for him? No;—he was forced upon me. A woman followed me, about eight years ago, in the fields adjoining to
my country ſeat, with a half-ſtarved boy in her hand, and aſked my charity for my grand-child: the impreſſion of the word, made me turn round involuntarily; and caſting my eyes upon him, I was rejoiced, not to find a feature of his mother's in all his face; and I began to feel ſomething like pity for him. In ſhort, he caught ſuch faſt hold by one of my fingers, that I aſked him careleſsly "if he would go home and live with me?" On which, he anſwered me ſo willingly "Yes," I took him at his word.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: And did never your regard for him, plead in his mother's behalf?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Never. For, by Heaven, I would as ſoon forgive the robber who met me laſt night at my own door, and, holding a piſtol to my breaſt, took from me a ſum to a conſiderable amount, as I would pardon her.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Did ſuch an accident happen to you?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Have you not heard of it?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: It is amazing we cannot put a ſtop to ſuch depredations.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Proviſions are ſo ſcarce!

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Miſs Wooburn, my Lord, if you are not engaged, will come and ſit an hour with you.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I have no company but what ſhe is perfectly acquainted with, and ſhall be glad of her viſit.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: You forget I am a ſtranger, and my preſence may not be welcome.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: A ſtranger! What, to my ward? to Lady Ramble? for that is the name which cuſtom would authoriſe her to keep; but ſuch courteſy ſhe diſdains, in contempt of the unworthy giver of the title.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I am intimate with Sir Robert, my Lord; and though I acknowledge that both you and his lady have cauſe for complaint, yet Sir Robert has ſtill many virtues.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Not one. He is the moſt vile, the moſt deteſtable of characters. He not only contradicted my will in the whole of his conduct, but he ſeldom met me that he did not give me ſome perſonal affront.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: It is, however, generally held better to be uncivil in a perſon's preſence, than in his abſence.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: He was uncivil to me in every reſpect.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: That I will deny; for I have heard Sir Robert, in your abſence, ſay ſuch things in your praiſe!—

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Moſt aſſuredly.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I wiſh he had ſometimes done me the honour to have ſpoken politely to my face.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: That is not Sir Robert's way;—he is no flatterer. But then, no ſooner has your back been turned, than I have heard him laviſh in your praiſe.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I muſt own, Mr. Harmony, that I never looked upon Sir Robert as incorrigible. I could always diſcern a ray of underſtanding, and a beam of virtue through all his foibles; nor would I have urged the divorce, but that I found his wife's ſenſibility could not bear his neglect; and even now, notwithſtanding her endeavour to conceal it, ſhe pines in ſecret, and laments her hard fortune. All my hopes of reſtoring her health reſt on one proſpect—that of finding a man worthy my recommendation for her ſecond huſband, and, by creating a ſecond paſſion, expel the firſt.—Mr. Harmony, you and I have been long acquainted—I have known your diſpoſition from your infancy— Now, if ſuch a man as you were to offer—

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: You flatter me.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I do not.—Would you venture to become her huſband?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I cannot ſay I have any particular deſire; but if it will oblige either you or her,—for my part, I think the ſhort time we live in this world, we ſhould do all we can to oblige each other.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p:
I ſhould rejoice at ſuch an union myſelf, and I
think I can anſwer for her.—You permit me then to make overtures to her in your name?

sp.speaker: HARMONY,
sp.p: This is rather a ſerious piece of buſineſs— However, I never did make a difficulty when I wiſhed to oblige a friend.—But there is one proviſo, my Lord; I muſt firſt mention it to Sir Robert.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Becauſe he and I have always been very intimate friends; and to marry his wife, without even telling him of it, will appear very uncivil!

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Do you mean then to aſk his conſent?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Not abſolutely his conſent; but I will inſinuate the ſubject to him, and obtain his approbation in a manner ſuitable to my own ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: You will oblige me then if you will ſee him as early as poſſible; for it is reported he is going abroad.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I will go to him immediately;—and, my Lord, I will do all in my power to oblige you, Sir Robert and the Lady; aſide—but as to obliging myſelf, that was never one of my conſiderations.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p:
I am ſorry to ſee you thus; you have been weeping? Will you ſtill lament your ſeparation from a
cruel huſband, as if you had followed a kind one to the grave?

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: By no means, my Lord. Tears from our ſex are not always the reſult of grief; they are frequently no more than little ſympathetic tributes which we pay to our fellow-beings, while the mind and the heart are ſteeled againſt the weakneſs which our eyes indicate.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Can you ſay, your mind and heart are ſo ſteeled?

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: I can: My mind is as firmly fixed againſt Sir Robert Ramble, as at our firſt acquaintance it was fixed upon him. And I ſolemnly proteſt—

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: To a man of my age and obſervation, proteſtations are vain.—Give me a proof that you have rooted him from your heart.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: Any proof you require, I will give without a moment's heſitation.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I take you at your word; and deſire you to accept a Gentleman, whom I ſhall recommend for your ſecond huſband. Miſs Wooburn ſtarts — You ſaid you would not heſitate a moment.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: I thought I ſhould not;—but this is ſomething. ſo unexpected—

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: You break your word then, and ſtill give cauſe for this ungrateful man, to ridicule your fondneſs for him.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: No, I will put an end to that humiliation; and whoever the Gentleman is whom you mean to propoſe—Yet, do not name him at preſent—but give me the ſatisfaction of keeping the promiſe I have made to you (at leaſt for a little time) without exactly knowing how far it extends; for, in return, I have a promiſe to aſk from you, before I acquaint you with the nature of your engagement.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I give my promiſe. Now name your requeſt.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: Then, my Lord, heſitating and confuſed—the law gave me back, upon my divorce from Sir Robert, the very large fortune which I brought to him.—I am afraid, that in his preſent circumſtances, to enforce the ſtrict payment of this debt, would very much embarraſs him.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: What if it did?

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: It is my entreaty to you (in whoſe hands is inveſted the power to demand this right of law) to lay my claim aſide for the preſent. Lord Norland offers to ſpeak I know, my Lord, what you are going to ſay; I know Sir Robert is not now, but I can never forget that he has been my huſband.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p:
To ſhew my gratitude for your compliance with the requeſt I have juſt made you, Goes to a table in the library here is the bond by which I am impowered to ſeize on the greateſt part of his eſtates in right of you: take the bond into your own poſſeſſion till your next huſband demands it
of you; and by the time you have called him huſband for a few weeks, this tenderneſs, or delicacy to Sir Robert, will be worn away.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: My Lord, I beg pardon; but I forgot to mention—

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Harmony, I have not ſeen you before I know not when: I am particularly happy at your calling juſt now, for I have— heſitating a little favour to aſk of you.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: If it were a great favour, Madam, you might command me.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: But—my Lord, I beg your pardon—but the favour I have to aſk of Mr. Harmony muſt be told to him in private.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Oh! I am ſure I have not the leaſt objection to you and Mr. Harmony having a private conference. I'll leave you together. Harmony appears embarraſſed. You do not derange my buſineſs— I'll be back in a ſhort time. Exit.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: Mr. Harmony, you are the very man on earth I moſt wanted to ſee. Harmony bows. I know the kindneſs of your heart, the liberality of your ſentiments, and I wiſh to repoſe a charge to your truſt, very near to me indeed—but you muſt be ſecret.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: When a Lady repoſes a truſt in me, I ſhould not be a man if I were not.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: I muſt firſt inform you, that Lord Norland has juſt drawn from me a promiſe, that I will once more enter into the marriage-ſtate; and without knowing to whom he intends to give me, I will keep my promiſe—But it is in vain to ſay, that, though I mean all duty and fidelity to my ſecond huſband, I ſhall not experience moments when my thoughts—will wander on my firſt.

sp.speaker: HARMONY,
sp.p: Hem!—Hem!— To her—Indeed?

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: I muſt always rejoice in Sir Robert's ſucceſſes, and lament over his misfortunes.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: If that is all—

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: No, I would go one ſtep further: Harmony ſtarts again I would ſecure him from thoſe miſfortunes, which to hear of, will diſturb my peace of mind. I know his fortune has ſuffered very much, and I cannot, will not, place it in the power of the man, whom my Lord Norland may point out for my next marriage, to diſtreſs him farther. —This is the writing, by which that Gentleman may claim the part of my fortune from Sir Robert Ramble, which is in landed property; carry it, my dear Mr. Harmony, to Sir Robert inſtantly; and tell him, that in ſeparating from him, I meant only to give him liberty; not make him the debtor, perhaps the priſoner of my future huſband.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Madam, I will moſt undoubtedly take this bond to my friend; but will you give me leave to ſuggeſt to you, that the perſon on whom you beſtow your hand, may be a little ſurpriſed to find, that while he is in poſſeſſion of you, Sir Robert is in the poſſeſſion of your fortune?

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: Do not imagine, Sir, that I ſhall marry any man, without firſt declaring what I have done—I only wiſh at preſent it ſhould be concealed from Lord Norland—When this paper is given, as I have required, it cannot be recalled; and when that is paſt, I ſhall divulge my conduct to whom I pleaſe; and firſt of all, to him, who ſhall offer me his addreſſes.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: And if he is a man of my feelings, his addreſſes will be doubly importunate for this proof of liberality to your former huſband. — But are you ſure, that in the return of this bond, there is no ſecret affection, no latent ſpark of love?

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p:
None. I know my heart; and if there was, I could not aſk you, Mr. Harmony (nor any one like you), to be the meſſenger of an imprudent paſſion. Sir Robert's vanity, I know, may cauſe him to judge otherwiſe; but undeceive him; let him know this is a ſacrifice to the golden principles of duty, and not an offering to the tinſelled ſhrine of love.
Enter Lord NORLAND. Put up the bond.— Harmony conceals it.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Well, my dear, have you made your requeſt?

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: And has he granted it?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord. I am going to grant it.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I ſincerely wiſh you both joy of this good underſtanding between you. But, Mr. Harmony, in a whiſper are not you going to Sir Robert?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I am going this moment.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Make haſte then, and do not forget your errand.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I ſha'n't forget my errand; it won't ſlip my memory—Good morning, my Lord —good morning, Madam. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Now, my dear, as you and Mr. Harmony ſeem, to be on ſuch excellent terms, I think I may venture to tell you (if he has not yet told you himſelf), that he is the man, who is to be your huſband.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: He! Mr. Harmony!—No, my Lord, he has not told me; and I am confident he never will.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: What makes you think ſo?

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: Becauſe—becauſe—he muſt be ſenſible he would not be the man I ſhould chooſe.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: And where is the woman who marries the man ſhe would chooſe? You are reverſing the order of ſociety; men, only, have the right of choice in marriage. Were women permitted theirs, we ſhould have handſome beggars allied to our nobleſt families, and no ſuch object in our whole iſland as an old maid.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: But being denied that choice, why forbid to remain as I am?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: What are you now? Neither a widow, a maid, nor a wife. If I could fix a term to your preſent ſtate, I ſhould not be thus anxious to place you in another.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: I am perfectly acquainted with your friendly motives, and feel the full force of your advice.— I therefore renew my promiſe—and although Mr. Harmony (in reſpect to the marriage ſtate) is as little to my wiſhes as any man on earth, I will nevertheleſs endeavour—whatever ſtruggles it may coſt me—to be to him, if he prefers his ſuit, a dutiful, an obedient—but, for a loving wife, that I can never be again.

div.head: SCENE, An Apartment at Sir RORBERT RAMBLE's.
div.stage: Enter Sir ROBERT and Mr. HARMONY.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: I thank you for this viſit. I was undetermined what to do with myſelf. Your company has determined me to ſtay at home.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I was with a Gentleman juſt now, Sir Robert, and you were the ſubject of our converſation.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Had it been a Lady, I ſhould be anxious to know what ſhe ſaid.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I have been with a Lady likewiſe; and ſhe made you the ſubject of her diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: But was ſhe handſome?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Very handſome.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: My dear fellow, what is her name? What did ſhe ſay, and where may I meet with her?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Her name is Wooburn.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: That is the name of my late wife.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: It is her I mean.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Zounds, you had juſt put my ſpirits into a flame, and now you throw cold water all over me.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I am ſorry to hear you ſay ſo, for I came from her this moment; and what do you think is the preſent ſhe has given me to deliver to you?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Pſhaw! I want no preſents. Some of my old love-letters returned, I ſuppoſe, to remind me of my inconſtancy?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Do not undervalue her generoſity: this is her preſent;—this bond, which has power to take from you three thouſand a year, her right.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Ah! this is a preſent indeed. Are you ſure you ſpeak truth? Let me look at it:—Sure my eyes deceive me!—No, by Heaven it is true! Reads The very thing I wanted, and will make me perfectly happy. Now I'll be generous again; my bills ſhall be paid, my gaming debts cancelled, poor Irwin ſhall find a friend; and I'll ſend her as pretty a copy of verſes as ever I wrote in my life.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Take care how you treat with levity a woman of her elevated mind. She charged me to aſſure you, "that love had no ſhare whatever in this act, but merely compaſſion to the embarraſſed ſtate of your affairs."

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Sir, I would have you to know, I am no object of compaſſion. However, a Lady's favour one cannot return; and ſo, I'll keep this thing.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Nay, if your circumſtances are different from what ſhe imagines, give it me back, and I will return it to her.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p:
No, poor thing! it would break her heart to ſend it back—No, I'll keep it—She would never forgive me, were I to ſend it back. I'll keep it. And ſhe is welcome to attribute her concern for me to what ſhe pleaſes. But ſurely you can ſee— you can underſtand—But Heaven bleſs her for
her love! and I would love her in return—if I could.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: You would not talk thus, if you had ſeen the firm dignity with which ſhe gave me that paper— "Aſſure him," ſaid ſhe, "no remaining affection comes along with it, but merely a duty which I owe him, to protect him from the humiliation of being a debtor to the man whom I am going to marry."

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT,
sp.p: Why, ſhe is not going to be married again!

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I believe ſo.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: But are you ſure of it, Sir? Are you ſure of it?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Both ſhe and her guardian told me ſo.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: That guardian, my Lord Norland, is one of the baſeſt, vileſt of men.—I tell you what, Sir, I'll reſent this uſage.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Wherefore?—As to his being the means of bringing about your ſeparation, in that he obliged you.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, he did, he certainly did;—but though I am not the leaſt offended with him on that head (for at that I rejoice), yet I will reſent his diſpoſing of her a ſecond time.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: And why?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Becauſe, little regard as I have for her myſelf, yet no other man ſhall dare to treat her ſo ill, as I have done.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Do not fear it—Her next huſband will be a man, who, I can ſafely ſay, will never inſult, or even offend her; but ſooth, indulge, and make her happy.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: And do you dare to tell me, that her next huſband ſhall make her happy? Now, that is worſe than the other—No, Sir, no man ſhall ever have it to ſay "he has made her either happy or miſerable," but myſelf.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I know of but one way to prevent it.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: And what is that?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Pay your addreſſes to her, and marry her again yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: And I would, rather than ſhe ſhould be happy with any body elſe. The devil take me if I would not.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: To ſhew that I am wholly diſintereſted in this affair, I will carry her a letter from you if you like, and ſay all I can in your behalf.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Now, my dear Harmony, you carry your good-natured ſimplicity too far. However, I thank you, I ſincerely thank you—But do you imagine I ſhould be ſuch a blockhead, as to make love to the ſame woman I made love to ſeven years ago, and who for the laſt ſix years I totally neglected?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Yes: for if you neglected her ſix years, ſhe will now be a novelty.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Egad, and ſo ſhe will. You are right.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: But being in poſſeſſion of her fortune, you can be very happy without her.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Take her fortune back, Sir. Taking the bond from his pocket and offering it to Harmony I would ſtarve, I would periſh, die in poverty and infamy, rather than owe an obligation to a vile, perfidious, inconſtant woman.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Conſider, Sir Robert, if you inſiſt on my taking this bond back, it may fall into the huſband's hands.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Take it back—I inſiſt upon it. Gives it him, and Harmony puts it up But, Mr. Harmony, depend on it, Lord Norland ſhall hear from me, in the moſt ſerious manner, for his interference—I repeat, he is the vileſt, the moſt villanous of men.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: How can you ſpeak with ſuch rancour of a nobleman, who ſpeaks of you in the higheſt terms?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Does he, 'faith?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: He owns you have ſome faults.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: I know I have.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: But he thinks your good qualities are numberleſs.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p:
Now dam'me, if ever I thought ſo ill of him, as I have appeared to do!—But who is the intended
huſband, my dear friend? Tell me, that I may laugh at him, and make you laugh at him.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: No, I am not inclined to laugh at him.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Is it old Solus?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: But I will bet you a wager it is ſomebody equally ridiculous.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I never bet.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Solus is mad for a wife, and has been praiſing mine up to the heavens; you need ſay no more; I know it is he.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Upon my honour, it is not. However, I cannot diſcloſe to you at preſent the perſon's name; I muſt firſt obtain Lord Norland's permiſſion.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: I ſhall aſk you no more. I'll write to her— ſhe will tell me;—or, I'll pay her a viſit, and aſk her boldly myſelf.—Do you think anxiouſly—do you think ſhe would ſee me?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: You can but try.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Mr. Solus.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Now I will find out the ſecret immediately.—I'll charge him with being the intended huſband.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p:
I will not ſtay to hear you.
Enter SOLUS. Mr. Solus, how do you do? I am extremely ſorry that my enagagements take me away as ſoon as you enter. Exit Harmony running, to avoid an explanation.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Sir Robert, what is the matter? Has any thing ruffled you? Why, I never ſaw you look more out of temper, even while you were married.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Ah! that I had never married! never known what marriage was! for, even at this moment, I feel its torments in my heart.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: I have often heard of the torments of matrimony; but I conceive, that at the worſt, they are nothing more than a kind of violent tickling, which will force the tears into your eyes, though at the ſame time you are burſting your ſides with laughter.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: You have defined marriage too favourably; there is no laughter in the ſtate: all is melancholy, all gloom.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Now I think marriage is an excellent remedy for the ſpleen. I have known a Gentleman at a feaſt receive an affront, diſguiſe his rage, ſtep home, vent it all upon his wife, return to his companions, and be as good company as if nothing had happened.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: But even the neceſſary expences of a wife ſhould alarm you.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: I can then retrench ſome of my own. Oh! my dear Sir, a married man has ſo many delightful privileges to what a bachelor has!—An old Lady will introduce her daughters to you in a diſhabille —"It does not ſignify, my dears, it's a married man"—One Lady will ſuffer you to draw on her glove—"Never mind, it's a married man"— Another will permit you to pull on her ſlipper; a third will even take you into her bed-chamber —"Pſhaw, it's nothing but a married man."

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
