sp.p: But the weight of your fetters will overbalance all theſe joys.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: And I cannot ſay, notwithſtanding you are relieved from the bond, that I ſee much joy or brightneſs here.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: I am not very well at preſent; I have the headach; and, if ever a wife can be of comfort to her huſband, it muſt be when he is indiſpoſed. A wife, then, binds up your head, mixes your powders, bathes your temples, and hovers about, in a way that is moſt endearing.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Don't ſpeak of it; I long to have one hover about me. But I will—I am determined I will, before I am a week older. Don't ſpeak, don't attempt to perſuade me not. Your deſcription has renewed my eagerneſs—I will be married.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p:
And without pretending not to know who you mean to make your wife, I tell you plainly, it is, Miſs Wooburn, it is my late wife.—I know you
made overtures to my Lord Norland, and that he has given his conſent.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: You tell me a great piece of news—I'll go aſk my Lord if it be true; and if he ſays it is, I ſhall be very glad to find it ſo.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: That is right, Sir; marry her, marry her;—I give you joy,—that's all.—Ha, ha, ha! I think I ſhould know her temper.—But if you will venture to, marry her, I ſincerely wiſh you happy.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: And if we are not, you know we can be divorced.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Not always. Take my advice, and live as you are.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: You almoſt ſtagger my reſolution.—I had painted ſuch bright proſpects in marriage:—Good day to you. Going, returns—You think I had better not marry?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: You are undone if you do.

sp.speaker: SOLUS,
sp.p: You ought to know from experience.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: From that I ſpeak.

sp.speaker: SOLUS,
sp.stage: Going to the door, and returning once or twice, as unſtable in his reſolution.
sp.p:
But then, what a poor diſconſolate object ſhall I live, without a wife to hover about me; to bind up my head, and bathe my temples! Oh! I am
impatient for all the chartered rights, privileges, and immunities of a married man. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Furies, racks, torments—I cannot bear what I feel, and yet I am aſhamed to own I feel any thing!

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: My dear Sir Robert, give me joy. Mrs. Placid and I are come to the very point you adviſed; matters are in the faireſt way for a ſeparation.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: I do give you joy, and moſt ſincerely.—You are right; you'll ſoon be as happy as I am. Sighing But would you ſuppoſe it? that deluded woman, my wife, is going to be married again! I thought ſhe had had enough of me!

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: You are hurt, I ſee, leſt the world ſhould ſay ſhe has forgot you.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: She cannot forget me; I defy her to forget me.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Who is her intended huſband?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Solus, Solus. An old man—an ugly man. He left me this moment, and owned it—owned it! Go after him, will you, and perſuade him not to have her.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: My advice will have no effect, for you know he is bent upon matrimony.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Then could not you, my dear Sir (as you are going to be ſeparated), could not you recommend him to marry your wife?—It will be all the ſame to him, I dare ſay, and I ſhall like it much better.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Ours will not be a divorce, conſider, but merely a ſeparate maintenance. But were it otherwiſe, I wiſh no man ſo ill, as to wiſh him married to Mrs. Placid.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: That is my caſe exactly. I wiſh no man ſo ill, as to wiſh him married to my Lady Ramble; and poor old Solus in particular, poor old man! a very good ſort of man—I have a great friendſhip for Solus.—I can't ſtay a moment in the houſe—I muſt go ſomewhere—I'll go to Solus.—No, I'll go to Lord Norland—No, I will go to Harmony; and then I'll call on you, and we'll take a bottle together; and when we are both free takes his hand we'll join, from that moment we'll join, to laugh at, to contemn, to deſpiſe all thoſe who boaſt of the joys of conjugal love. Exeunt.

div.head: ACT IV.
SCENE I. An Apartment at Mr. HARMONY's.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: AND now, for one of the moſt painful taſks that brotherly love ever draws upon me; to tell another, the ſuit, of which I gave him hope, has failed.—Yet, if I can but overcome Captain Irwin's delicacy ſo far, as to prevail on him to accept one proof more of my good wiſhes towards him;— but to a man of his nice ſenſe of obligations, the offer muſt be made with caution.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Mr. Harmony, I beg your pardon: I come in thus abruptly, from the anxiety I feel concerning what paſſed between us this morning in reſpect to Miſs Wooburn. You have not changed your mind, I hope?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Indeed, my Lord, I am very ſorry that it will not be in my power to oblige you.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND,
sp.p: How, Sir? Did not you give me your word?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Only conditionally, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: And what were the conditions?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Have you forgot them? Her former huſband.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Sir Robert Ramble is in his carriage at the door, and, if you are at leiſure, will come in.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Deſire him to walk up. I have your leave, I ſuppoſe, my Lord?Exit Servant.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Yes; but let me get out of the houſe without meeting him. Going to the oppoſite door Can I go this way?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Why ſhould you ſhun him?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Becauſe he uſed his wife ill.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: He did. But I believe he is very ſorry for it. —And as for you, he ſaid to me only a few hours ago—but no matter.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: What did he ſay? I inſiſt upon knowing.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Why then he ſaid, "that if he had a ſacred truſt to repoſe in any one, you ſhould be the man on earth, to whom he would confide it."

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Well, I am in no hurry; I can ſtay a few minutes.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p:
Oh! Harmony! I am in ſuch a diſtracted ſtate
of mind— Seeing Lord Norland, he ſtarts, and bows with the moſt humble reſpect.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Sir Robert, how do you do?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: My Lord, I am pretty well.—I hope I have the happineſs of ſeeing your Lordſhip in perfect health.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Very well, Sir, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Indeed, my Lord, I think I never ſaw you look better.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Mr. Harmony, you and Sir Robert may have ſome buſineſs—I'll wiſh you a good morning.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I fancy Sir Robert has nothing particular.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing, I aſſure you, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: However, I have buſineſs myſelf in another place, and ſo you will excuſe me. Going.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT,
sp.p: My Lord—Lord Norland,—I truſt you will excuſe my enquiries.—I hope, my Lord, all your family are well?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: All very well.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p:
Your little Elevè,—Maſter Edward,—the young Gentleman you have adopted—I hope he is
well— heſitating and confuſed And—your Ward, Sir—Miſs Wooburn—I hope, my Lord, ſhe is well?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Yes, Sir Robert, Miſs Wooburn is tolerably well.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Only tolerably, my Lord? I am ſorry for that.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I hope, my Lord, you will excuſe my mentioning the ſubject; but I was telling Sir Robert juſt now, of your intentions reſpecting a ſecond marriage for that Lady; but Sir Robert does not appear to approve of the deſign.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: What objection can he have?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: My Lord, there are ſuch a number of bad huſbands; there are ſuch a number of diſſipated, unthinking, unprincipled men!—And—I ſhould be extremely ſorry to ſee any Lady with whom I have had the honour of being ſo cloſely allied, united to one who would undervalue her worth.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Pray, Sir Robert, were you not then extremely ſorry for her, while ſhe was united to you?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Very ſorry for her indeed, my Lord. But, at that time, my mind was ſo taken up with other cares, I own I did not feel the compaſſion which was her due; but, now that I am ſingle, I ſhall have leiſure to pay her more attention; and ſhould I find her unhappy, it muſt, inevitably, make me ſo.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Depend upon it, that on the preſent occaſion, I ſhall take infinite care in the choice of her huſband.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: If your Lordſhip would permit me to have an interview with Miſs Wooburn, I think I ſhould be able at leaſt—

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: You would not ſure inſult her by your preſence?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: I think I ſhould be able at leaſt to point out an object worthy of her taſte—I know what ſhe will like better than any body in the world.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Her requeſt has been, that I may point her out a huſband the reverſe of you.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Then, upon my honour, my Lord, ſhe won't like him.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Have not you liked women the reverſe of her?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, perhaps I have, and perhaps I ſtill do. I do not pretend to love her; I did not ſay I did; nay, I poſitively proteſt I do not; but this indifference I acknowledge as one of my faults; and, notwithſtanding all my faults, give me leave to acknowledge my gratitude that your Lordſhip has nevertheleſs been pleaſed to declare you think my virtues are numberleſs. Lord Norland ſhews ſurpriſe.

sp.speaker: HARMONY,
sp.p: Huſh, huſh!—Don't, talk of your virtues now.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Sir Robert, to all this incoherent language, this is my anſwer, this is my will: The Lady, to whom I have had the honour to be guardian, ſhall never (while ſhe calls me friend) ſee you more.

div.stage: Sir ROBERT, at this ſentence, ſtands ſilent for ſome time, then, ſuddenly recollecting himſelf

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Lord Norland, I am too well acquainted with the truth of your word, and the firmneſs of your temper, to preſs my ſuit one ſentence farther.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I commend your diſcernment.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: My Lord, I feel myſelf a little embarraſſed.— I am afraid I have made myſelf a little ridiculous upon this occaſion—Will your Lordſhip do me the favour to forget it?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I will forget whatever you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: HARMONY
sp.p: I am ſorry to ſee you going away in deſpair.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: I never did deſpair in my life, Sir; and while a woman is the object of my wiſhes, I never will.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: What did he ſay?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: That he thought your conduct that of a juſt and an upright man.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p:
To ſay the truth, he has gone away with better
manners than I could have imagined, conſidering his jealouſy is provoked.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Ah! I always knew he loved his wife, notwithſtanding his behaviour to her; for, if you remember, he always ſpoke well of her behind her back.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: No, I do not remember it.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Yes, he did; and that is the only criterion of a man's love, or of his friendſhip.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: A young gentleman is at the door, Sir, enquiring for Lord Norland.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Who can it be?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Your young gentleman from home, I dare ſay. Deſire him to walk in. Bring him here.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: What buſineſs can he have to follow me?

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: Oh, my Lord, I beg your pardon for coming hither; but I come to tell you ſomething you will be glad to hear.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Good Heaven! how like his mother!

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND,
sp.p: I begin to think he is—but he was not ſo when I firſt took him. No, no, if he had, he would not have been thus near me now;—but to turn him away becauſe his countenance is a little changed, I think would not be right.

sp.speaker: EDWARD,
sp.p: Pray, Sir, did you know my mother?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I have ſeen her.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: Did you ever ſee her, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I thought you had orders never to enquire about your parents? Have you forgot thoſe orders?

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: No, my Lord; but when this gentleman ſaid I was like my mother—it put me in mind of her.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: You do not remember your mother, do you?

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: Sometimes I think I do. I think ſometimes I remember her kiſſing me, when ſhe and my father went on board of a ſhip; and ſo hard ſhe preſſed me—I think I feel it now.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Perhaps ſhe was the only Lady that ever ſaluted you?

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: No, Sir; not by many.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p:
But pray, young man (to have done with this
ſubject), what brought you here? You ſeem to have forgot your errand?

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: And ſo I had, upon my word. Speaking of my mother, put it quite out of my head.—But, my Lord, I came to let you know, the robber who ſtopped you laſt night is taken.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I am glad to hear it.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: I knew you would; and therefore I begged to be the firſt to tell you.

sp.speaker: HARMONY,
sp.p: Should you know the perſon again?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I cannot ſay I ſhould, his face ſeemed ſo much diſtorted.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Ay, wretched man! I ſuppoſe with terror.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: No; it appeared a different paſſion from fear.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: Perhaps, my Lord, it was your fear that made you think ſo.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: No, Sir, I was not frightened.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: Then why did you give him your money?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: It was ſurpriſe cauſed me to do that.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: I wondered what it was! You ſaid it was not fear, and I was ſure it could not be love.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: How has he been taken?

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: A perſon came to our ſteward, and informed againſt him;—and, Oh! my Lord, his poor wife told the officers who took him, they had met with misfortunes, which ſhe feared had cauſed a fever in her huſband's head; and, indeed, they found him too ill to be removed; and ſo, ſhe hoped, ſhe ſaid, "that as a man, not in his perfect mind, you would be merciful to him."

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I will be juſt.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: And that is being merciful, is it not, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Not always.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: I thought it had been.—It is not juſt to be unmerciful, is it?

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: Then it muſt be juſt, to have mercy.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: You draw a falſe concluſion. Great as is the virtue of mercy, juſtice is greater ſtill. Juſtice holds its place among thoſe cardinal virtues which include all the leſſer.—Come, Mr. Harmony, will you go home with me? And before I attend to this buſineſs, let me perſuade you to forget there is ſuch a perſon in the world as Sir Robert, and ſuffer me to introduce you to Miſs Wooburn, as the man who—

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: I beg to be excuſed—Beſides the conſideration of Sir Robert, I have another reaſon why I cannot go with you. The melancholy tale which this young gentleman has been telling, has caſt a gloom on my ſpirits which renders me unfit for the ſociety of a Lady.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Now I ſhould not be ſurpriſed were you to go in ſearch of this culprit and his family, and come to me to intreat me to forego the proſecution; but, before you aſk me, I tell you it is in vain—I will not.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Lord Norland, I have lately been ſo unſucceſſful in my petitions to you, I ſhall never preſume to interpoſe between your rigour and a weak ſufferer more.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Plead the cauſe of the good, and I will liſten; but you find none but the wicked for your compaſſion.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: The good in all ſtates, even in the very jaws of death, are objects of envy; it is the bad who are the only real ſufferers: There, where no internal conſolation cheers, who can refuſe a little external comfort?—And let me tell you, my Lord, that amidſt all your authority, your ſtate, your grandeur, I often pity you. Speaking with unaffected compaſſion.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Good-day, Mr. Harmony; and when you have apologiſed for what you have ſaid, we may be friends again. Exit, leading off Edward.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Nay, hear my apology now. I cannot—no, it is not in my nature to live in reſentment, nor under the reſentment of any creature in the world.

div.head: SCENE II. An Apartment at Lord NORLAND's.
div.stage: Enter Sir ROBERT RAMBLE, followed by a Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Do not ſay who it is—but ſay a Gentleman who has ſome very particular buſineſs with her.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. Going.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Pray, Servant returns You are but lately come into this ſervice, I believe?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Only a few days, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: You don't know me, then?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: I am very glad of it. So much the better. Go to Miſs Wooburn, with a Stranger's compliments who is waiting, and who begs to ſpeak with her upon an affair of importance.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p:
I wiſh I may die if I don't feel very unaccountably! How different are our ſenſations towards
our wives, and all other women! This is the very firſt time ſhe has given me a palpitation ſince the honey-moon.

div.stage: Enter Miſs WOOBURN, who ſtarts on ſeeing Sir Robert;—he bows in great confuſion.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: Support me, Heaven!Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT,
sp.stage: Bows repeatedly, and does not ſpeak till after many efforts.
sp.p: Was ever man in ſuch confuſion before his wife!Aſide.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: Sir Robert, having recovered in ſome meaſure, from the ſurpriſe into which this intruſion firſt threw me, I have only to ſay, that whatever pretence may have induced you to offer me this inſult, there are none to oblige me to bear with it.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Lady Ramb— recalling himſelf Miſs Woo— She turns Lady Ramble— recalling himſelf again Miſs Wooburn—Madam—You wrong me— There was a time when I inſulted you, I confeſs; but it is impoſſible that time ſhould ever return.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: While I ſtay with you, I incur the danger.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT,
sp.p: Nay, liſten to me as a friend, whom you have ſo often heard as an enemy.—You offered me a favour by the hands of Mr. Harmony—

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: And is this the motive of your viſit—this the return—

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: No, Madam, that obligation was not the motive which drew me hither—The real cauſe of this ſeeming intruſion is—you are going to be married once more, and I come to warn you of your danger.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: That you did ſufficiently in the marriage-ſtate.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: But now I come to offer you advice that may be of the moſt material conſequence, ſhould you really be determined to yield yourſelf again into the power of a huſband.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: Which I moſt aſſuredly am.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Happy, happy man! How much is he the object of my envy! None ſo well as I, know how to envy him, becauſe none ſo well as I, know how to value you. She offers to go Nay, by Heaven you ſhall not go till you have heard all that I came to ſay!

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: Speak it then inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: No, it would take whole ages to ſpeak; and ſhould we live together, as long as we have lived together, ſtill I ſhould not find time to tell you— how much I love you.

div.stage: A loud rapping at the ſtreet-door.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: That, I hope, is Lord Norland.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p:
And what has Lord Norland to do with ſouls
free as ours? Let us go to Scotland again; and again bid defiance to his ſtern commands.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: Be aſſured, that through him only, will I ever liſten to a ſyllable you have to utter.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: One ſyllable only, and I am gone that inſtant.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: Well, Sir?

div.stage: He heſitates, trembles, ſeems to ſtruggle with himſelf; then approaching her ſlowly, timidly, and as if aſhamed of his humiliation, kneels to her— She turns away.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT,
sp.p: Maria, Maria, look at me!—Look at me in this humble ſtate—Could you have ſuſpected this, Maria?

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: No: nor can I conceive what this mockery means.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: It means, that now you are no longer my wife, you are my Goddeſs; and thus I offer you my ſupplication, that (if you are reſolved not to live ſingle) amongſt the numerous train who preſent their ſuit, you will once more ſelect me.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: You!—You who have treated me with cruelty; who made no ſecret of your love for others—but gloried, boaſted of your gallantries?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p:
I did, I did—But here I ſwear, only truſt me again—do but once more truſt me, and I ſwear
by all I hold moſt ſacred, that I will for the future carefully conceal all my gallantries from your knowledge—though they were ten times more frequent than before.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: Oh, my dear Miſs Wooburn—What! Sir Robert here too! Goes to Sir Robert and ſhakes hands How do you do, Sir Robert? Who would have thought of ſeeing you here? I am glad to ſee you though, with all my heart; and ſo I dare ſay is Miſs Wooburn, though ſhe may not like to ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: You are impertinent, Sir.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: What, for coming in? I will go away then.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Do, do—There's a good boy—do.

sp.speaker: EDWARD,
sp.p: I cannot help laughing, though, to ſee you two together!—For you know you never were together when you lived in the ſame houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Leave the room inſtantly, Sir, or I ſhall call Lord Norland.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: Oh, don't take that trouble, I will call him myſelf. Runs to the door—My Lord, my Lord, pray come here this moment—As I am alive, here is Sir Robert Ramble along with Lady Ramble!

div.stage: Sir Robert looks confounded, Lord Norland points to Edward to leave the room.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Sir Robert, on what pretence do you come hither?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: On the ſame pretence, as when I was for the firſt time admitted into your houſe; to ſolicit this Lady's hand. And, after having had it once, no force ſhall compel me to take a refuſal.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I will try however—Madam, quit the room inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: My Lord, ſhe ſhall not quit it.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I command her to go.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: And I command her to ſtay.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Which of us will you obey?

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: My inclination, my Lord, diſpoſes me to obey you;—but I have ſo lately been accuſtomed to obey him, that cuſtom inclines me to obey him ſtill.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: There! There! There, my Lord! Now I hope you will underſtand better for the future, and not attempt to interfere between a man and his wife.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND,
sp.p: Be explicit in your anſwer to this queſtion— Will you conſent to be his wife?

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: No, never.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Zounds, my Lord, now you are hurrying matters.—You ſhould do it by gentle means;—let me aſk her gently. With a moſt ſoft voice Maria, Maria, will you be my wife once again?

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: So you ſaid ſeven years ago when I aſked you, and yet you conſented.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: And now, Sir Robert, you have had your anſwer; leave my houſe. Going up to him.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; but not without my other half.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: "Your other half?"

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Yes; the wife of my boſom—the wife, whom I ſwore at the altar to love and to cheriſh, and, forſaking all others, cleave only to her as long as we both ſhould live.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: You broke your oath, and made the contract void.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: But I am ready to take another oath; and another after that, and another after that—And, Oh, my dear Maria, be propitious to my vows, and give me hopes you will again be mine. He goes to her, and kneels in the moſt ſupplicating attitude.

div.stage: Enter EDWARD, ſhewing in Mr. SOLUS and Mr. PLACID; Edward points to Sir Robert (who has his back to them) and goes off.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT,
sp.stage: Still on his knees, and not perceiving their entrance.
sp.p: I cannot live without you.—Receive your penitent huſband, thus humbly acknowledging his faults, and imploring you to accept him once again.

sp.speaker: SOLUS,
sp.p: Now, is it wonderful that I ſhould want a wife?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: And is it to be wondered at, if I ſhould heſitate about parting with mine?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT
sp.p: Mr. Solus, Mr. Placid, I am highly diſpleaſed that my private actions ſhould be thus inſpected.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: No one ſhall perſuade me now, to live a day without a wife.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: And no one ſhall perſuade me now, not to be content with my own.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: I will procure a ſpecial licence, and marry the firſt woman I meet.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Mr. Solus, you are, I believe, intereſted in a peculiar manner, about the marriage of this Lady.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p:
And, poor man, you are ſick, and want ſomebody
to "bathe your temples," and to hover about you.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: You come in moſt opportunely, my dear Mr. Solus, to be a witneſs—

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: "My dear Mr. Solus!"

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: To be a witneſs, Madam, that a man is miſerable without a wife. I have been a fatal inſtance of that, for ſome time.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: Come to me then, and receive a leſſon.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: No, Madam, he ſhall not come to you; nor ſhall he receive a leſſon. No one ſhall receive a leſſon from you, but me.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Sir Robert, one would ſuppoſe by this extraordinary behaviour, you were jealous.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: And ſo I am, my Lord; I have cauſe to be ſo.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: No cauſe to be jealous of Mr. Solus—He is not Miſs Wooburn's lover, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Then, my Lord, I verily believe it is yourſelf. Yes, I can ſee it is; I can ſee it by her eyes, and by every feature in your face.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: Oh! my good friend, Mr. Placid, only liſten to him.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: And why "my good friend, Mr. Placid?" To Placid. By Heavens, Sir, I believe that you only wiſhed to get rid of your own wife, in order to marry mine.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: I do not wiſh to part with my own wife, Sir Robert, ſince what I have juſt ſeen.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT,
sp.stage: Going up to Solus and Lord Norland.
sp.p: Then, pray, gentlemen, be ſo good as to tell me, which of you two is the happy man, that I may know how to conduct myſelf towards him?

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Do you inſult me, Maria?—Oh! have pity on my ſufferings.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: If you have a mind to kneel down again, we will go out of the room.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Juſt as I was comforting myſelf with the proſpect of a divorce, I find my inſtructor and director pleading on his knees to be remarried.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: What were you ſaying about a divorce?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Now, down on your knees, and beg pardon.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: My dear Mrs. Placid, if this viſit is to me, I take it very kind.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Not abſolutely to you, my dear. I ſaw Mr. Placid's carriage at the door, and ſo I ſtepped in to deſire him to go home. Go home directly.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Preſently, my dear; I will go preſently.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Preſently won't do; I ſay directly. There is a lady at my houſe in the greateſt poſſible diſtreſs whiſpers him—Lady Eleanor—I never ſaw a creature in ſuch diſtraction; Raiſing her voice —therefore go home this moment; you ſha'n't ſtay an inſtant longer.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Egad, I don't know whether I will marry or no.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Why don't you go, Mr. Placid, when I bid you?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: No;—I think I won't marry.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: But, my dear, will not you go home with me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Did not I tell you to go by yourſelf?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: No;—I am ſure I won't marry.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: And now, Mr. Solus and Sir Robert, theſe ladies may have ſome private converſation. Do me the favour to leave them alone.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p:
My Lord, with your leave we will retire. Turns
when ſhe gets to the door. Sir Robert, I have remained in your company, and compelled myſelf to the painful taſk of hearing all you have had to ſay, merely for the ſatisfaction of expoſing your love, and then enjoying the triumph of bidding you farewell for ever. Exit with Mrs. Placid.

sp.speaker: SOLUS,
sp.p: He turns pale at the thoughts of loſing her. Yes, I think I'll marry.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Come, Sir Robert, it is in vain to loiter; your doom is fixed.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT,
sp.p: Shall I then never again know what it is to have a heart like her's, to repoſe my troubles on?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Yes, I am pretty ſure I'll marry.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: —A friend in all my anxieties, a companion in all my pleaſures, a phyſician in all my ſickneſſes—

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Yes, I will marry.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Come, come, Sir Robert, do not let you and I have any diſpute. Leading him towards the door.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Senſeleſs man, not to value thoſe bleſſings—Not to know how to eſtimate them, till they were loſt.

sp.speaker: SOLUS,
sp.p: Yes,—I am determined;—nothing ſhall prevent me—I will be married. Exit.

div.head: ACT V.
SCENE I. An Apartment at Lord NORLAND's.
div.stage: Enter HAMMOND, followed by Lady ELEANOR.

sp.speaker: HAMMOND.
sp.p: MY Lord is buſily engaged, Madam; I do not ſuppoſe he would ſee any one, much leſs a ſtranger.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: I am no ſtranger.

sp.speaker: HAMMOND.
sp.p: Your name then, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: That, I cannot ſend in. But tell him, Sir, I am the afflicted wife of a man, who for ſome weeks paſt has given many fatal proofs of a diſordered mind. In one of thoſe fits of phrenſy, he held an inſtrument of death, meant for his own deſtruction, to the breaſt of your Lord (who by accident that moment paſſed), and took from him, what he vainly hoped might preſerve his own life, and relieve the wants of his family. But his paroxyſm over, he ſhrunk from what he had done, and gave the whole he had thus unwarrantably taken, into a ſervant's hands to be returned to its lawful owner. The man, admitted to this confidence, betrayed his truſt, and inſtead of giving up what was ſo ſacredly delivered to him, ſecreted it; and, to obtain the promiſed reward, came to this houſe, but to inform againſt the wretched offender; who now, only reſting on your Lord's clemency, can eſcape the direful fate he has incurred.

sp.speaker: HAMMOND.
sp.p: Madam, the account you give, makes me intereſted in your behalf, and you may depend, I will repeat it all with the greateſt exactneſs.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR,
sp.p: This is my father's houſe! It is only through two rooms and one ſhort paſſage, and there he is ſitting in his ſtudy. Oh! in that ſtudy, where I (even in the midſt of all his buſineſs) have been ſo often welcome; where I have urged the ſuit of many an unhappy perſon, nor ever urged in vain. Now I am not permitted to ſpeak for myſelf, nor have one friendly voice to do that office for me, which I have ſo often undertaken for others.

sp.speaker: HAMMOND.
sp.p: My Lord ſays, that any petition concerning the perſon you come about, is in vain. His reſpect for the laws of his country demands an example ſuch as he means to make.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Am I, am I to deſpair then? To Hammond Dear Sir, would you go once more to him, and humbly repreſent—

sp.speaker: HAMMOND.
sp.p: I ſhould be happy to oblige you, but I dare not take any more meſſages to my Lord; he has given me my anſwer.—If you will give me leave, Madam, I'll ſee you to the door.

div.stage: Croſſes to the other ſide, and Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p:
Miſery—Diſtraction!—Oh, Mr. Placid! Oh,
Mr. Harmony! Are theſe the hopes you gave me, could I have the boldneſs to enter this houſe? But you would neither of you undertake to bring me here!—neither of you undertake to ſpeak for me!

div.stage: She is following the Servant; Edward walks ſoftly after her, till ſhe gets near the door; he then takes hold of her gown, and gently pulls it; ſhe turns and looks at him.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: Shall I ſpeak for you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Who are you, pray, young Gentleman? Is it you, whom Lord Norland has adopted for his ſon?

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: I believe he has, Madam; but he has never told me ſo yet.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: I am obliged to you for your offer; but my ſuit is of too much conſequence for you to undertake.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: I know what your ſuit is, Madam, becauſe I was with my Lord when Hammond brought in your meſſage; and I was ſo ſorry for you, I came out on purpoſe to ſee you—and, without ſpeaking to my Lord, I could do you a great kindneſs—if I durſt.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: What kindneſs?

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: But I durſt not—No, do not aſk me.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: I do not. But you have raiſed my curioſity; and in a mind ſo diſtracted as mine, it is cruel to excite one additional pain.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: I am ſure I would not add to your grief for the world.—But then, pray do not ſpeak of what I am going to ſay.—I heard my Lord's lawyer tell him juſt now, "that as he ſaid he ſhould not know the perſon again, who committed the offence about which you came, and as the man who informed againſt him was gone off, there could be no evidence that he did the action, but from a book, a particular pocket-book, of my Lord's, which he forgot to deliver to his ſervant with the notes and money to return, and which was found upon him at your houſe: and this, Lord Norland will affirm to be his."—Now, if I did not think I was doing wrong, this is the very book— Takes a pocket-book front his pocket I took it from my Lord's table;— but it would be doing wrong, or I am ſure I wiſh you had it. Looking wiſhfully at her.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: It will ſave my life, my huſband's and my children's.

sp.speaker: EDWARD,
sp.p: But what is to become of me?

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: That Providence, who never puniſhes the deed, unleſs the will be an accomplice, ſhall protect you for ſaving one, who has only erred in a moment of diſtraction.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: I never did any thing to offend my Lord in my life;—and I am in ſuch fear of him, I did not think I ever ſhould.—Yet, I cannot refuſe you;— take it.— Gives her the book. But pity me, when my Lord ſhall know of it.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Oh! ſhould he diſcard you for what you have done, it will embitter every moment of my remaining life.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: Do not frighten yourſelf about that.—I think he loves me too well to diſcard me quite.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: Does he indeed?

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: I think he does;—for often, when we are alone, he preſſes me to his boſom ſo fondly, you would not ſuppoſe.—And, when my poor nurſe died, ſhe called me to her bed-ſide, and told me (but pray keep it a ſecret)—ſhe told me I was—his grandchild.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: You are—you are his grand-child—I ſee,—I feel you are;—for I feel that I am your mother. Embraces him. Oh! take this evidence back returning the book—I cannot receive it from thee, my child;—no, let us all periſh, rather than my boy, my only boy, ſhould do an act to ſtain his conſcience, or to loſe his grand-father's love.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: The name of the perſon with whom you lived in your infancy, was Heyland?

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: It was.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p:
I am your mother; Lord Norland's only child, Edward kneels who, for one act of diſobedience, have been driven to another part of the globe in
poverty, and forced to leave you, my life, behind. She embraces and raiſes him. Your father, in his ſtruggles to ſupport us all, has fallen a victim;— but Heaven, which has preſerved my child, will ſave my huſband, reſtore his ſenſe, and once more—

sp.speaker: EDWARD,
sp.p: I hear my Lord's ſtep,—he is coming this way: —Begone, mother, or we are all undone.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: No, let him come —for though his frown ſhould kill me, yet muſt I thank him for his care of thee.
sp.stage: She advances towards the door to meet him.
sp.p: Falling on her knees. You love me,— 'tis in vain to ſay you do not: You love my child; and with whatever hardſhips you have dealt, or ſtill mean to deal by me, I will never ceaſe to think you love me, nor ever ceaſe my gratitude for your goodneſs.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Where are my ſervants? Who let this woman in?

div.stage: She riſes, and retreats from him alarmed and confuſed.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: Oh, my Lord, pity her.—Do not let me ſee her hardly treated—Indeed I cannot bear it.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND,
sp.p: What was your errand here? If to ſee your child, take him along with you.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: I came to ſee my father;—I have a houſe too full of ſuch as he already.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: How did ſhe gain admittance?

sp.speaker: HAMMOND.
sp.p: With a petition, which I repeated to your Lordſhip. Exit Hammond.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Her huſband then it was, who— To Lady Eleanor But let him know, for this boy's ſake, I will no longer purſue him.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR.
sp.p: For that boy's ſake you will not purſue his father; but for whoſe ſake are you ſo tender of that boy? 'Tis for mine, for my ſake; and by that I conjure you— Offers to kneel.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Your prayers are vain— To Edward. Go, take leave of your mother for ever, and inſtantly follow me; or ſhake hands with me for the laſt time, and inſtantly begone with her.

div.stage: Edward ſtands between them in doubt for ſome little time: looks alternately at each with emotions of affection; at laſt goes to his grandfather, and takes hold of his hand.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: Farewell, my Lord, —it almoſt breaks my heart to part from you;—but, if I have my choice, I muſt go with my mother.

div.stage: Lady Eleanor and her Son go off on the oppoſite ſide.

div.head: SCENE II. Another Apartment at Lord NORLAND's.
div.stage: Enter Miſs WOOBURN and Mrs. PLACID.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Well, my dear, farewell.—I have ſtaid a great while longer than I intended—I certainly forgot to tell Mr. Placid to come back after he had ſpoken with Lady Eleanor, or he would not have taken the liberty not to have come.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: How often have I lamented the fate of Lord Norland's daughter! But, luckily, I have no perſonal acquaintance with her, or I ſhould probably feel a great deal more on her account than I do at preſent.—She had quitted her father's houſe before I came to it.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: My whole life is paſſed in endeavouring to make people happy, and yet they won't let me.—I flattered myſelf, that after I had reſigned all pretenſions to you, Miſs Wooburn, in order to accommodate Sir Robert—that, after I had told both my Lord and him, in what high eſtimation they ſtood in each other's opinion, they would of courſe be friends; or, at leaſt, not have come to any deſperate quarrel:—inſtead of which, what have they done, but, within this hour, had a duel!—and poor Sir Robert—

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: For Heaven's ſake, tell me of Sir Robert—

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p:
You were the only perſon he mentioned after
he received his wound; and ſuch encomiums as he uttered—

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: Good Heaven! If he is in danger, it will be vain to endeavour to conceal what I ſhall ſuffer.

div.stage: Retires a few paces to conceal her emotions.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Was my huſband there?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: He was one of the ſeconds.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Then he ſhall not ſtir out of his houſe this month, for it.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: He is not likely; for he is hurt too.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: A great deal hurt?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Don't alarm yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: I don't.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Nay, if you had heard what he ſaid!

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: What did he ſay?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: How tenderly he ſpoke of you to all his friends—

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: But what did he ſay?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: He ſaid you had imperfections.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Then he told a falſehood.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: But he acknowledged they were ſuch as only evinced a ſuperior underſtanding to the reſt of your ſex;—and that your heart—

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID,
sp.p: I am ſure I am very ſorry that any misfortune has happened to him, poor, ſilly man! But I do not ſuppoſe drying up her tears at once he will die.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: If you will behave kind to him, I ſhould ſuppoſe not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Mr. Harmony, if Mr. Placid is either dying or dead, I ſhall behave with very great tenderneſs; but if I find him alive and likely to live, I will lead him ſuch a life as he has not led a long time.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Then you mean to be kind? But, my dear Miſs Wooburn, going to her why this ſeeming grief? Sir Robert is ſtill living; and ſhould he die of his wounds, you may at leaſt conſole yourſelf, that it was not your cruelty which killed him.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: Rather than have ſuch a weight on my conſcience, I would comply with the moſt extravagant of his deſires, and ſuffer his cruelty to be the death of me.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: If thoſe are your ſentiments, it is my advice that you pay him a viſit in his affliction.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: Oh no, Mr. Harmony, I would not for the univerſe. Mrs. Placid, do you think it would be proper?

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: No, I think it would not—Conſider, my dear, you are no longer a wife, but a ſingle Lady, and would you run into the clutches of a man?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: He has no clutches, Madam; he is ill in bed, and totally helpleſs.—But, upon recollection, it would, perhaps, be needleſs to go; for he may be too ill to admit you.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: If that is the caſe, all reſpect to my ſituation, my character, ſinks before the ſtrong deſire of ſeeing him once more. Oh! were I even married to another, I feel, that in ſpite of all my private declarations, or public vows, I ſhould fly from him, to pay my duty where it was firſt plighted.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: My coach is at the door; ſhall I take you to his houſe? Come, Mrs. Placid, wave all ceremonious motives on the preſent melancholy occaſion, and go along with Miſs Wooburn and me.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: But, Mrs. Placid, perhaps poor Mr. Placid is in want of your attendance at home.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: No, they were both carried in the ſame carriage to Sir Robert's.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN,
sp.stage: As Harmony leads her to the door.
sp.p: Oh! how I long to ſee my dear huſband, that I may conſole him!

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Oh! how I long to ſee my dear huſband, that I may quarrel with him!Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III. The Hall at Sir ROBERT RAMBLE's.

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN.
sp.p: Porter, porter, how can you ſleep at this time of the day?—It is only eight o'clock.

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: What did you want, Mr. William?

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN.
sp.p: To tell you my maſter muſt not be diſturbed, and ſo you muſt not let in a ſingle creature.

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: Mr. William, this is no leſs than the third time I have received thoſe orders within this half hour: —Firſt, from the butler, then from the valet, and now from the footman.—Do you all ſuppoſe I am ſtupid?

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN.
sp.p: I was bid to tell you. I have only done what I was deſired; and mind you do the ſame. Exit.

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: I'll do my duty, I warrant you. I'll do my duty. A loud rapping at the door And there's a rap to put my duty to the trial. Opens the door.

div.stage: Enter HARMONY, Miſs WOOBURN, and Mrs. PLACID.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p:
Theſe ladies come on a viſit to Sir Robert.
Deſire one of the ſervants to conduct them to him inſtantly.

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, that is impoſſible—My maſter is not —

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: We know he is at home, and therefore we can take no denial.

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: I own he is at home, Sir; but indeed he is not in a ſituation—

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: We know his ſituation.

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: Then, Madam, you muſt ſuppoſe he is not to be diſturbed. I have ſtrict orders not to let in a ſingle ſoul.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: This Lady, you muſt be certain, is an exception.

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: No Lady can be an exception in my maſter's preſent ſtate; for I believe, Sir, but perhaps I ſhould not ſpeak of it, I believe my maſter is nearly gone.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: Oh! ſupport me, Heaven!

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: But has he his ſenſes?

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: Not very clearly, I believe.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: Oh! Mr. Harmony, let me ſee him before they are quite loſt.

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: It is as much as my place is worth, to let a creature farther than this hall; for my maſter is but in the next room.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: That is a dining-room. Is not he in bed?

sp.speaker: HARMONY,
sp.p: In caſes of wounds, the patient is oftentimes propped up in his chair.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: Does he talk at all?

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, I heard him juſt now very loud.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN,
sp.p: I think I hear him rave.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: No, that murmuring is the voice of other perſons.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: The Doctors in conſultation, I apprehend.—Has he taken any thing?

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: A great deal, I believe, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: No amputation, I hope?

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: What, Madam?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: He does not underſtand you. To Miſs Wooburn. —Come, will you go back?

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: Do, my Lady, and call in the morning.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p:
By that time he may be totally inſenſible, and
die without knowing how much I am attached to him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: And my huſband may die without knowing how much I am enraged with him!—Mr. Harmony, never mind this fooliſh man, but force your way into the next room.

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, you muſt not. Pray, Mr. Harmony, pray, Ladies, go away.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: Yes, I muſt go from my huſband's houſe for ever; never to ſee that, or him again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: She is fainting—open the windows—give her air.

sp.speaker: PORTER.
sp.p: Pray go away:—There is plenty of air in the ſtreets, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Scoundrel! Your impertinence is inſupportable. Open theſe doors; I inſiſt on their being opened.

div.stage: He thruſts at a door in the centre of the ſtage; it opens, and diſcovers Sir Robert and Mr. Placid at a table ſurrounded by a company of Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p:
A ſong—a ſong—another ſong—
Miſs Wooburn, all aſtoniſhment, is ſupported by Mr. Harmony and Mrs. Placid—the Porter runs off.
Oh! what do I ſee!—Women! Ladies! Celeſtial beings we were talking of.—Can this be real? Sir Robert and Mr. Placid come forward—Sir Robert perceiving it is Miſs Wooburn, turns himſelf to the company Gentlemen, Gentlemen, married
men and ſingle men, hear me thus publicly renounce every woman on earth but this; and ſwear henceforward to be devoted to none but my own wife. Goes to her in raptures.

sp.speaker: PLACID,
sp.stage: Looking at Mrs. Placid, then turning to the Company.
sp.p: Gentlemen, Gentlemen, married men and ſingle men, hear me thus publicly declare, I will henceforth be maſter;—and from this time forward, will be obeyed by my wife. Sir Robert waves his hand, and the door is cloſed on the company of Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Mr. Placid—Mr. Placid, are not you afraid?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: No, Madam;—I have conſulted my friends, I have drank two bottles of wine, and I never intend to be afraid again.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN,
sp.p: Can it be, that I ſee you without a wound?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: No, my life, that you do not; for I have a wound through my heart, which none but you can cure. But in deſpair of your aid, I have flown to wine, to give me a temporary relief by the loſs of reflection.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Mr. Placid, you will be ſober in the morning.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Yes, my dear; and I will take care that you ſhall be dutiful in the morning.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p:
For ſhame! How can you treat Mrs. Placid thus? You would not, if you knew what kind things ſhe has been ſaying of you; and how anxious
ſhe was when I told her you were wounded in a duel.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: Was not I, Mr. Harmony?Burſting into tears.

sp.speaker: PLACID,
sp.stage: Aſide to Harmony and Sir Robert.
sp.p: I did not know ſhe could cry;—I never ſaw it before, and it has made me ſober in an inſtant.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: Mr. Placid, I rely on you to conduct me immediately from this houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: That I proteſt againſt; and will uſe even violent meaſures to prevent it.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Lord Norland.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: He will protect me.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Who ſhall protect you in my houſe but I? My Lord, ſhe is under my protection; and if you offer to take her from me, I'll exert the authority of a huſband, and lock her up.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND,
sp.p: Have you been deluded hither, and wiſh to leave the place with me? Tell me inſtantly, that I may know how to act.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: My Lord, I am ready to go with you, but—

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p:
—But you find ſhe is inclined to ſtay; and do have
ſome compaſſion upon two people that are ſo fond of you.

div.stage: Enter Mr. SOLUS, dreſt in a ſuit of white clothes.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: I am married!—I am married! —Wiſh me joy! I am married!

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: I cannot give you joy, for envy.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Nay, I do not know whether you will envy me much when you ſee my ſpouſe—I cannot ſay ſhe was exactly my choice. However, ſhe is my wife now; and that is a name ſo endearing, I think I love her better ſince the ceremony has been performed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. PLACID.
sp.p: And pray, when did it take place?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: This moment. We are now returning from a friend's houſe, where we have been joined; and I felt myſelf ſo happy, I could not paſs Sir Robert's door, without calling to tell him of my good fortune.—And, as I ſee your Lady here, Sir Robert, I gueſs you are juſt married too; and ſo I'll hand my wife out of the carriage, and introduce the two Brides to each other. Exit Solus.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: You ſee, my Lord, what conſtruction Mr. Solus has put on this Lady's viſit to me. And by Heaven, if you take her away, it will be ſaid, that ſhe came and offered herſelf, and that I reject her!

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: Such a report would kill me.

div.stage: Enter SOLUS, leading on Miſs SPINSTER.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Miſtreſs Solus. Introducing her.

sp.speaker: HARMONY,
sp.p: My Relation! Dear Madam, by what ſtrange turn of fortune do I ſee you become a wife?

sp.speaker: Mrs. SOLUS.
sp.p: Mr. Harmony, it is a weakneſs I acknowledge; but you can never want an excuſe for me, when you call to mind "the ſcarcity of proviſions."

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Mr. Harmony, I have loved her ever ſince you told me ſhe ſpoke ſo well of me behind my back.

div.stage: And whiſpers Mr. HARMONY, who follows him off.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: I agree with you, Mr. Solus, that this is a moſt excellent proof of a perſon's diſpoſition; and in conſideration, Sir Robert, that, throughout all our many diſagreements, you have ſtill preſerved a reſpect for my character in my abſence, I do at laſt ſay to that Lady, ſhe has my conſent to truſt you again.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: And ſhe will truſt me; I ſee it in her ſmiles. Oh! unexpected ecſtaſy!

sp.speaker: HARMONY,
sp.stage: Holding a letter in his hand.
sp.p:
Amidſt thoſe bright proſpects of joy which this company are contemplating, I come to announce an event that ought to cloud the ſplendour of the horizon.—A worthy, but an ill-fated man, whom
ye were all acquainted with, has juſt breathed his laſt.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Do you mean the huſband of my daughter?

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: Do you mean my nephew?

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Is it my friend?

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: And my old acquaintance?

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Did Mr. Irwin poſſeſs all thoſe titles you have given him, Gentlemen? Was he your ſon? To Lord Norland Your nephew? To Solus Your friend? To Mr. Placid And your old acquaintance? To Sir Robert—How ſtrange he did not know it!

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: He did know it.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Still more ſtrange that he ſhould die for want, and not apply to any of you!

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: What! Die for want in London! Starve in the midſt of plenty!

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: No; but he ſeized that plenty, where law, where honour, where every ſocial and religious tie forbad the treſpaſs; and in puniſhment of the guilt, has become his own executioner.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Then my daughter is wretched, and her boy involved in his father's infamy.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: The fear of his ghoſt haunting me, will diſturb the joys of my married life.

sp.speaker: PLACID.
sp.p: Mrs. Placid, Mrs. Placid, my complying with your injunctions in reſpect of Mr. Irwin, will make me miſerable for ever.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN.
sp.p: I wiſh he had applied to me.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: And as I refuſed him his requeſt. I would give half my eſtate he had not applied to me.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: And a man who always ſpoke ſo well of you all behind your backs!—I dare ſay, that, in his dying moments, there was not one of you whom he did not praiſe for ſome virtue.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p: No, no—when he was dying he would be more careful of what he ſaid.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Sir Robert, good-day. Settle your marriage as you and your Lady ſhall approve; you have my good wiſhes. But my ſpirits have received too great a ſhock to be capable of any other impreſſion at preſent.

sp.speaker: Miſs WOOBURN,
sp.p: Nay, ſtay, my Lord.

sp.speaker: SOLUS.
sp.p:
And, Mrs. Solus, let me hand you into your carriage to your company; but excuſe my going home with you. My ſpirits have received too
great a ſhock, for me to be capable of any other impreſſion at preſent.

sp.speaker: HARMONY,
sp.p: Now, ſo loth am I to ſee any of you, only for a moment, in grief, while I have the power to relieve you, that I cannot help—Yes, my philanthropy will get the better of my juſtice.

div.stage: Goes to the door, and leads on Lady Eleanor, Irwin, and Edward.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND
sp.stage: Runs to Irwin, and embraces him.
sp.p: My ſon! Irwin falls on his knees I take a ſhare in all your offences—The worſt of accomplices, while I impelled you to them.

sp.speaker: IRWIN,
sp.p: I come to offer my returning reaſon; to offer my vows, that, while that reaſon continue, ſo long will I be penitent for the phrenſy which put your life in danger.

sp.speaker: Lady ELEANOR,
sp.stage: Moving timidly to her Father, leading Edward by the hand.
sp.p: I come to offer you this child, this affectionate child; who, in the midſt of our careſſes, droops his head and pines for your forgiveneſs.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: Ah! there is a corner of my heart left to receive him. Embraces him.

sp.speaker: EDWARD.
sp.p: Then, pray, my Lord, ſuffer the corner to be large enough to hold my mother.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: My heart is ſoftened, and receives you all. Embraces Lady Eleanor, who falls on her knees; he then turns to Harmony—Mr. Harmony, I thank you, I moſt ſincerely thank you for this, the joyfulleſt moment of my life. I not only experience releaſe from miſery, but return to happineſs.

sp.speaker: HARMONY
sp.stage: Goes haſtily to Solus, and leads him to Irwin; then turns to Mr. and Mrs. Placid.
sp.p: And now, that I ſee you all reconciled, I can ſay, there are not two enemies in the whole circle of my acquaintance, that I have not within theſe three days made friends.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: Very true, Harmony; for we ſhould never have known half how well we all love one another, if you had not told us.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: And yet, my good friends, notwithſtanding the merit you may attribute to me, I have one moſt tremendous fault; and it weighs ſo heavy on my conſcience, I would confeſs what it is, but that you might hereafter call my veracity in queſtion.

sp.speaker: Sir ROBERT.
sp.p: My dear Harmony, without a fault, you would not be a proper companion for any of us.

sp.speaker: Lord NORLAND.
sp.p: And while a man like you, may have (among ſo many virtues) ſome faults; let us hope there may be found in each of us, (among all our faults) ſome virtues.

sp.speaker: HARMONY.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord,—and notwithſtanding all our faults, it is my ſincere wiſh, that the world may ſpeak well of us—behind our backs.

div.head: EPILOGUE.

lg.l: "EACH has his fault," we readily allow,
To this Decree, our deareſt friends muſt bow;
One is too careleſs, one is too correct,
All, ſave our own ſweet ſelf, has ſome defect:
And characters to ev'ry virtue dear,
Sink from a hint, or ſuffer by a ſneer.
"Sir Harry Blink! Oh, he's a worthy man,
"Still anxious to do all the good he can;
"To aid diſtreſs, wou'd ſhare his laſt poor guinea,
"Delights in kindneſs—but then, what a ninny!"
Lady Doll Primroſe ſays to Lady Sly,
"You know Miſs Tidlikins? Yes—looks awry—
"She's going to be married,—that won't mend it;—
"They ſay ſhe'll have a fortune,—and ſhe'll ſpend it.
"I hope your La'aſhip viſits Lady Hearty,
"We meet to-night—a moſt delightful party.
"I don't like Dowagers, who would be young,
"And 'twixt ourſelves they ſay—She has a tongue."
If ſuch the general blame that all await,
Say, can our Author 'ſcape the general fate?
Some will diſlike the ſaucy truths ſhe teaches,
Fond bachelors, and wives who wear the breeches.
"Let me be wedded to a handſome youth,"
Cries old Miſs Mumblelove, without a tooth.
"Theſe worn-out Beaux, becauſe they've heavy purſes,
"Expect us, ſpinſters, to become their nurſes.
"To love, and be beloved 's the happy wife,
"A mutual paſſion is the charm of life."
"Marriage is Heaven's beſt gift, we muſt believe it,
"Yet ſome with weak ideas can't conceive it.—
"Poor Lady Sobwell's grief the town wou'd ſtun;
"Oh, Tiffany! Your miſtreſs is undone.
"Dear Ma'am—I hope my Lord is well—don't cry—
"Hav'n't I cauſe?—The monſter will not die—
"The reaſon why I married him, is clear,
"I fondly thought he cou'd not live a year:
"But now his dropſy's better, and his cough—
"Not the leaſt chance for that to take him off.
"I, that cou'd have young huſbands now in plenty,
"Sha'n't be a widow till I'm one-and-twenty—
"No lovely weeds—No ſweet diſhevell'd hair—
"Oh! I cou'd cry my eyes out in deſpair."
Sir Triſtram Teſty, worn with age and gout;
Within, all ſpleen, and flannel all without;
Roars from his elbow-chair, "Reach me my crutches,
"Oh! if Death had my wife within his clutches,
"With what delight her funeral meats I'd gobble,
"And tho', not dance upon her grave, I'd hobble;
"No longer then, my peace ſhe could unhinge,
"I ſhou'd cut capers ſoon, tries to jump, and ſtumbles
Zounds! What a twinge!"—
Theſe playful pictures of diſcordant life,
We bring to combat diſcontent and ſtrife,
And, by the force of contraſt, ſweetly prove
The charm that waits on fond and faithful love:
When ſuited years, and pliant tempers join,
And the heart glows with energy divine,
As the lov'd offspring of the happy pair
Oft climb the knee, the envied kiſs to ſhare.
Such joys this happy country long has known,
Rear'd in the Cot, reflected from the Throne;
Oh! may the glorious zeal, the loyal ſtand
Which nobly animate this envied land,
Secure to every breaſt, with glad increaſe,
The heartfelt bleſſings of domeſtic peace!
